thread.text:
So ever since I got my V30, people have mentioned they would get a text twice from me. I thought it was sporadic, but turns out it is every text I send to anyone, they just don't always say something!
I use the Google messenger app and Nova Prime. From the research I've done this is usually a problem with the stock message app re-sending the same message as the 3rd party app, and is not isolated to the V30 or LG. 
I've done all the suggestions of disabling permissions and data for the LG app (since they don't let you uninstall it) and tried a different 3rd party app (Textra) without any luck. 
So I finally give up yesterday and resign myself to having to use the LG app even though I hate it so I stop annoying everyone I text, and it is doing the same thing! 
I'm at the end of my rope on ideas short of totally wiping the phone as a last resort. Any experience with this or suggestions would be greatly appreciated. 😊

I didn't have that issue but did have an odd texting issue and it seems to be isolated to the Google Android messaging app. I wouldn't receive texts from certain people but would receive them in the LG app even though they wasn't default. I thought the issue was fixed but then I couldn't receive pictures from one person in that app. I hate the stock app and refuse to use it. Have you tried Textra? I haven't had any issues yet and get it was worth paying a few bucks to remove ads.

replies.text: Yeah I tried Textra and had the same issue. I hate the stock app too, but even it is sending duplicates so even that didn't fix the issue.

thread.text:
Whose your carrier? Have you contacted them? This is way above my level of tech savvy-ness. 
With my issue, I tried deleting all my texts, uninstalling the Android messaging app, Deleted cache and data from the LG messaging app. Then reinstalled Android messaging. It seemed like it was working until I realized I wasn't getting my Dad's pictures and texts from a couple other people only in that app. I know your issue is different and it's happening in all apps but I just thought I'd share what I did to try and resolve it.

replies.text:
T-Mobile. No haven't contacted them yet. 
I'm thinking of doing the same thing you did and try to wipe everything clean and go from there first. Kind of like doing a reboot before calling the help desk as you know that's the first thing they will ask!

thread.text: I'm also on Tmobile. My phone started doing this yesterday. I had recently turn on data saver. I turned data saver off and it hasn't happened since.

title: How is everyone's LG V30 Holding up?

thread.text:
Are the LG V30's just as responsive as they were when you guys first got them? I haven't purchased one yet but I plan to. I just wanted to know if there was any jank in the software that causes it to slow down. 
(Coming from a janky S7 Edge)

replies.text: Fantastic. I got it on launch

I have the LG V20 for over a year. ZERO problems, the phone functions like it did brand new. Other phones slow down after some time, LG never purposely slow down their devices. If you're worried about the phone slowing down, don't update it. If it ain't broke, don't fix it. Also, don't install too many junk apps, or just use Greenify to hibernate them. LG so far has been an honest company.

thread.text: it sounds you prefer the pure android so go for the pixel 2.

replies.text: On a Sprint family plan so thats not really an option sadly.

thread.text: I've had it since it came out, what's that, 5 months now, about? It's still as responsive as it was day 1, zero issues. I had to reset my S7 two months after getting it because it lagged so bad. Last year I got the S8+ but I never really liked the size and FPS location so all last year I used my Huawei Mate 9. I think the Mate 9 and V30 are the smoothest phones I've owned and I update 3x per year on T-Mobile’s Jump ON DEMAND plan.

replies.text: That's great to hear! I'm about to upgrade and was going to dismiss the S9 because of its predecessors performance. I guess I will go with the V30.
Samsung phones are known to slow down after awhile. Why is that? I'm not sure. Ask a Note 4 owner.

Note 4 owner here and can confirm Samsung phones 'don't just slow down after a while'. The Note 4's V6 update was not a good one and didn't run well on the phone but that's different to 'just slowing down' and my Note 8's performance is as good as when it started, perhaps in a few years when it gets a few big OS updates it won't be as well optimised but that's not unique to Samsung.
If you interview people who never updated the Note 4, they'll tell you the phone is working flawlessly. Ask those that updated already, they will complain so much. Kinda sucks about that.
You know it's not 3 times a year anymore right?
What is it then ? I thought it was 3 times a year but u must keep the device for 30 days intill u upgrade again
It's not, what is it now? Since when? The last phone I got on the plan was the V30 the day it came out.

thread.text: I don't own a V30, but do own the V20 and it's still performing exceptionally well. I doubt the V30 will slow down anytime soon.

I've had mine since launch day also. I have over 100 apps installed. Zero issues, great screen, no lag. I do have the habit of restarting all my phones once a week. The only issue has been finding a good screen protector. The sound with my SoundMagic E80s is phenomenal.

Had the V30 since launch day as well, no slowdowns of any kind. Although on my unit the USB C port has now carved a little inward so now it's a bit harder to get the phone to fast charge. There's also an issue where if it's running more than 7 days without a restart all data will just randomly stop working (including wifi) and the only way to fix it is a soft reset. Other than that, great phone and it has the best sound of any phone I've owned since my HTC One M8.

replies.text:
Ditto on both comments. I'm glad I'm not the only one who has found that I have to push in the charging cable just a touch firmer (only periodically) to get the fast charge going.
I also agree with other posters who noted on the periodic restart of the phone.
The one thing that has started to happen, but not all the time, is that when I punch in my voicemail password that the screen will go blank after each number and not record the press. At that point, I restart the device and all is well.

thread.text: Had the V30 since launch day as well, no slowdowns of any kind. Although on my unit the USB C port has now caved a little inward so now it's a bit harder to get the phone to fast charge. There's also an issue where if it's running more than 7 days without a restart all data will just randomly stop working (including wifi) and the only way to fix it is a soft reset. Other than that, great phone and it has the best sound of any phone I've owned since my HTC One M8.
You know it's not 3 times a year anymore right?

No issues since I bought it when it came out. 
When I got my 256GB iPhone 8 Plus, the weight of the V30 how light it is somewhat bothered me. I don't know, it feels "cheap?"

replies.text: That's what you get when you basically have circuitry sandwiched between sheets of glass. There's no reassuring heft going on.

thread.text: This phone is amazing and with a 2 year warranty. I absolutely love it no complaints at all LG really came through with a exceptional phone.

Funny you should ask: today my camera started to lag taking photos at a botanical garden. Not sure what happened. Also, the battery seems a little weaker than right of the box. But I still like it just fine.

Another person that has had the V30 from the start.
NO issues! Battery life is great, no lag or other problems.
At this point, no reason to upgrade.
Have you made a decision yet, OP - did you buy the V30?

My V30 is still fantastic! I bought it the week it came out. It has no lag. Battery life is amazing.
I am loving that it has a 2 year warranty.
I wish T-Mo and LG would get Oreo sorted out and installed.

I'm so pissed off right now! I thought I would warn v30 owners and potential buyers. I just got the v30 3 weeks ago and while I was outside in the cold, my phone was in my pocket (in a case) and when I came back in where it was warm I noticed the back of my phone has a huge crack! Keep in mind, nothing hit my phone and I've not dropped it! Well I told LG customer service if they wouldn't warranty the device out I was going back to Samsung. Their response was the most ignorant I've ever received from a customer service representative. The response was..... I understand. I mean really?! What a joke. Buyer beware!

replies.text:
I've had nothing but good experiences with LG. They were quick to repair my G6 when the fingerprint sensor died and the Sim tray broke.
They more recently, with my V10, replaced the motherboard under warranty, even though the device was out of warranty.
Maybe not threatening the company had something to do with the exceptional customer service. 
My V30 is perfect. Even when I have it in my back pocket working in the cold Wisconsin winter.

I didn't threaten them. I just told it like it is, they won't back up a defective product so I'll go to a company that does! I'm glad your v30 is perfect, but a phone shouldn't just crack like mine did
Do you have a chat transcript? Maybe you came off too strong and the guy didn't want to have it..

Is it covered under warranty? How cold was it when you were outside and how warm was it when you came back inside? Sudden temperature change can crack any object, heat expands and cold shrinks. In extreme weather, you should consider buying a Samsung Galaxy Active phone which is designed for such conditions. Or the Cat5 phone.

thread.text: I'm sorry your V30 has a crack in it! How big is it? Have you made any decisions on what you are going to do?

replies.text: Yeah, I'm going to bail on LG and get the s9+

thread.text: A couple years ago they fixed my bootlooped G4 at least 6mos out of warranty, paid 2-day shipping both ways, and even sent me a box! Sorry they won't cover your crack...hopefully an isolated incident.

replies.text: Thanks! Maybe I just got a representative that was having a bad day. Either way I think I'm going with the Samsung Galaxy s9+. Apparently it has 20% thicker glass and stronger frame

If you talk to them in the right way, they might. If you can somehow explain it wasn't your fault, sometimes they will fix it for free. They can tell if it was dropped.. there would be a dent. A phone suddenly cracking would be a clean crack.

If you are abrasive with them it feels good but it crushes your chances of a result. Control yourself use finesse. 
What I do is just call back until I get an agent that is having a good day and wants to help.
I've done it with airlines, the electric company, the phone company, hotels etc. Just keep calling and say "ok I'll call back another time" when you aren't getting what you want. 
Keep calling until you get someone willing to grease the wheels. Showing any emotion doesn't help.

thread.text: Sudden temperature changes can cause glass to fracture. Say...going from notably cold environment to a notably warmer environment. I think that's just physics or something, but perhaps I'm being mistaken.

replies.text: It's true. If you have a heater, turn it facing towards a TV, speaker, or clothes drawer... you'll will hear a CRACK. That's the plastic expanding from the heat. Doesn't really damage it though, just a sudden change in physics and the heat expanding it.

thread.text: I've had this v30+ out there in 0 degrees F with me, multiple times, and did not have a problem. Meanwhile my Samsung screen began to flicker.

replies.text: I have the LG V20, I was just in Canada in the icy mountains which was about 0 degrees as well. No problems whatsoever.

thread.text: It's hard to get anything done from warranty when there's physical damage.

As someone who has worked in customer service for almost five years, I too would recommend using a friendly and/or civil demeanour. Though it's totally understandable to be frustrated, using understanding and/or pleasant-to-the-product language may help (like, "This is an awesome phone, I love using it; it's just too bad that this happened! I'm sure you'll be able to offer a couple of different solutions so we can fix this, so I can get back to using it every day"). If someone told me they'd shop or take their business elsewhere, to be honest, I'd just shrug it off. Things like that don't really have much affect, as sales reps and others in the industry are told those things often.
Again, I definitely understand your anger and frustration. But approaching LG reps in a different fashion could help you.

It definitely sucks, and I'm sure you're telling the truth, but looking at it from LG's side, I'm sure nobody has ever called support claiming that their phone just cracked for no good reason and wanting LG to fix it for free. I'd be skeptical as well. I guess that's why phone insurance exists.

While drastic temp changes can break glass, it would have to have been a sudden, large change to simply crack the back panel that way. Something tells me there was pressure or the phone was inadvertently bumped at some point. If it was that cold out, it's possible the glass was more susceptible to cracking even with a bump that would typically not cause said damage.
It is possible that your panel spontaneously cracked due to the temperature change, as any tempered glass has that possibility built in. However, LG may not fully honor that type of occurrence.
As others have said, it would appear that your salty attitude with the CSR probably soured your experience before it even began.

If I remember high school science from the last century...... 
That happens with glass, could happen with a lot of material. 
Don't blame LG. Yes, maybe they could have been nicer about it when you called.
But, a Sammy could have the same issue, under the same settings.
Lateck,

I'm a former Verizon rep, I've seen a few customers come into the store because their displays cracked while out in the cold. 
Two guys were snowmobiling in below zero temperatures, phones in their coat pockets, both had a cracked display. One was an iPhone, the other an Android. I think it was Samsung or Motorola. 
It sucks, but I don't think it's the result of LG making a low quality phone.
Did you try taking it to your carrier and explaining what happened?

We had quite a few weeks of up to minus 18° Celsius here in Austria and a lot of snow.
I was out and about with my 20 month old son, who was riding his new sledge for the first time.
Needless to say, the V30 came in handy for taking lot's of pics and vids.
The cold didn't harm it though.
Maybe there is a possibility to argue, that if other phones don't experience this problem, this really might be a problem of your device and therefore a matter of warranty?

what's headphones take advantage of the LG V30 DAC te best?
I've tried the following so far: in latest order
Beyerdynamic 770PRO 250 ohm
Mass Drop Sennheiser 6XXX
ATH 40X
Monolith 560
Fostex T50RP MKIII
didn't seem like the V30 could drive the 250 ohm 770 Pros as mentioned by one reviewer.
I'm looking to replace carrying around my cowon plenue and fiio x3 2nd gen players with a separate power amp along with my phone and just use my phone as an audioplayer for my HD flac/DSD rips.

replies.text: I use the AT ATH 50X WHEN HOME, AND THE KLIPSCH xr8i when on the go.

The ATH m40x already sounds good. Anything better would be overkill. If you really want good sound, I recommend the Mackie MR5 MKII studio speakers with a subwoofer attached, you will be blown away! With a HiFi FLAC or 320kbps MP3 plus the V30's DAC... you will get almost live performance quality.

thread.text:
Yes it's pretty cool. I have the v30+.
I've used a Sony PHA-1A Amp with my PSB M4U2 and Grado 325e headphones to get really good mid-fi level sound for a couple of years now but found the tethering and lugging around so annoying, buzz kill to the sound experience.
Now I can just plug right into phone for a level of sound very similar to that. 
How did the v30 do with the HD6xx and the Monolith? I'm Wondering if the v30 could drive HE400i or Grado RS2e or even GS2000e.
I really enjoy the senn hd599. Much better than ath m50x.

replies.text: Of course. The Senn is a better headphone (IMO). I have Senn 595s (that I got in 2006) and 650s (amongst a slew of others) and my 595s are not only the most comfortable set I have but they sound great too. I would imagine the 599s only sound better.

thread.text:
i picked up the massdrop nuforce edc and edc3
does anyone know about the soundmagic E80C?
some other forums have pointed to that earbud match for the V30 DAC
Also what about the RHA T10i or Sennheiser IE 800S?
although a grand for IEMs for a phone sounds overkill
I might take a look at the HD598 since my 6XXX are open backs and not good for commuting.
And as far as the rec on the Mackie MR5 MKII. How do they compare to the Micca PBA42V with built in amp?
Also how does the quad DAC in the v30 compare to the Wolfson DAC on the iPod 5.5 or Blackberry Playbook?

replies.text: I bought SoundMagic E80s (~$60). It has 64 ohm impedance so it always trigger HIM.

thread.text:
okay found it
VE Monk Plus earbuds
$11 on Amazon used to be $5
The VE Zen to move up to 300+ ohms but over $100
pretty f'n eye opening
Tried them with my cowon Plenue and a series of amps and they seem to come alive on the v30
Still need to test the KZ ZST and K56 along with the soundmagic 80C this week 
But you can't go wrong with $11 although they don't seal out the world like the Beyerdynamic 770 and ATH40Xs do
but they are so much more pocketable and way more cost effective
Blows the old legendary monoprice cheapos out of the water
Gonna try and mold some custom sugru earpieces to get them to lock in and seal out the world and see the effect of the sound

Update
Just finish testing the following IEMs with my V30
Nuforce Massdrop EDC - $60
VE Monk Plus - $12
KZ ATR - $11
Soundmagic E80S - $50
Koss KSC75 $16
I am still waiting to test these
KS ZTE - $21
Shozy Hibiki - $63
Massdrop Nuforce EDC3 - $99
HD Tracks used include
Cassandra Wilson - Another Country
**** Hyman - Garson "Trio Blues"
Emilie-Claire Barlow - Mineiro de Caracao
Tedeschi Trucks Band - I Pity The Fool (live)
Melody Gardot - Bad News
Steve Kindler/Teja Bell - Kaimana
of the group I had high hopes for the Soundmagic since it had the best fit other than the KZ ATR.
but of the group in my opinion, the $12 VE Monk Plus still sounds the best. The Soundmagic E80s sounded way too bright even though the lows were solid. The stinging highs just everwhelmed the rest. The KZ ATR weren't bad either just a little bassy for my tastes but a good noise blocking fit like the soundmagics. The Mids on the Monk Plus makes the listening experience really enjoyable, kind of like being there. The Nuforce's sounded muddy and dampened compared to the rest of the cheaper IEMs
For the price LG should just include a set of the monks with each of their phones that have the quad DAC and they would have allot of surprised and happy clients.
At home the Massdrop Sennheiser 6xxx, and ATH M40x's would be my choice 
The way the Monk comes live really makes me wonder about the Zens which are at 300+ohms versus 64ohms with the Monks but the cost is the restricting factor. I did give in to their promo of their new Monk IEs Smalls and Biggie
I'll report my experiences with these other affordable IEMs later.

replies.text: Thanks for this. I was all set to get the SoundMagic e80c to go with the V30+, since the higher impedance triggers the DAC. My favorite audio implementation is BoomSound from HTC, but given their struggles, I don't see myself getting another HTC. Do you have experience with BoomSound? I know it's just a bit punchy with the bass. Which in-ear buds that you've tested closely replicates BoomSound-type audio in your opinion?

thread.text:
since I don't have an HTC 10 I'm not sure of what effect the boomsound has on ear buds but it kind of reminds me of how my Blackberry playbooks sound when you are watching video or listening to music. I think the USB C out has potential for better audio but you'll need a special cable or phones.
so far I'll say for the V30 you can't go wrong with the VE Monk Plus's as a portable rig but they don't have any sound isolation. 
I built my own custom ear molds using Shark Fin and sugru to try and help the bass on the sound magic 80's but it didn't work also tried a bunch of other tips with no success. Only if you EQ the sound can you make them sound better. I'll try a long burn in as well.
The KZ ATRs and ZST had good isolation and were a little bright and inexpensive like the Monk Plus just a little more heft to carry around compare to the Monks.
I don't really listen to rap or bass heavy music so I've never been a sony earbuds or beats fan but if you love bass and can deal with the bulk then the Beyerdynamic 770Pros 250 ohm are the ones to get along with the ATH 40X over ears. The Sennheisers are also great but they are all 1000 times the size of the Monk OPlus and almost 10-20 times the cost. 
So far the Chesky 30th Anniversary album from HD tracks sounds just as great on my V30 with the monks as it does on my Fiio X3 and Cowon Plenue with a headphone amp. 
Does anyone know if the V30 can play apple lossless or ALAC?

Need some insight before I commit to buy this phone. I've been reading reviews on the v30 and the concerns I have are battery life through the day not great. Camera on auto not great and screen issues on early models. 
Please let me know how battery is holding up for you guys through the day, 
How camera on auto performs and if LG had issues with the screen, thanks.

replies.text:
I leave the house with 100% battery and come home 12 hours later with 80% after a day of light use. Even with intermittent heavy use I've never got the battery down to 70%.
Its easily the best battery experience I've ever had. I barely use fast charge. At home I just top-up with old Belkin wireless charging pads scattered around the house, for a little top-up while in the shower and cooking before going out. 
I could never use the charging pads on previous phones. The previous phones drained too much throughout the day to make slow wireless pads feasible, which was a bummer because they are quite nice to use. 
Battery and DAC quality are revolutionary here. 
Battery has become a complete non-issue thanks to v30+. Which, as a long-time Samsung user is shocking to me. 
No screen issues. No funny tint of any kind. It's a gorgeous very impressive screen but still not as jaw dropping as Samsungs saturated contrasty screen. But surprisingly close with better detail than my old Galaxy S6 Edge, and nicely saturated colors.
But the camera IMO is a disappointment. I may have gotten spoiled, it is after all a camera that takes quite nice photos right from my phone...but Samsung was better in this regard imo, in auto-mode. I've heard others say they love it. I have not had any luck and I've taken my usual few hundred pictures in the last few months with it.
Somehow every picture that I take in automatic mode, the ones that aren't completely blurry, one thing somewhere on the screen will be fairly sharp but most things are blurry to some extent.

thread.text: Don't use the camera much, but completely agree with rfan8312.

I agree the battery life is stellar. My screen is just fine, not as over-saturated as the Galaxy S7 edge that preceded it, which I actually prefer. The main camera isn't as good in low light as the GS7 was (not horrible, but not as good), but perfectly fine in good light. The wide angle camera is great though. I didn't think I'd use it, but it has come in handy on several occasions.

The battery life of my V30 is great. With medium use, it lasts all day.
The screen is great. 
I have no complaints against the camera. While it is not the best available, I find it more than adequate as a cel phone camera when in auto mode; I have no problems running it in manual mode when I need. I have DSLRs available for important pictures or those in difficult lighting circumstances.
I love the camera but my battery life - when I first got it, all day easily. Lately it's been a bit less stellar. But I am a battery jinx.

Having considered the V30 for myself, I've watched a lot of review videos. Battery and screen are great. Camera, from what I recall, is good. Of course, camera ratings are often subjective and you'll get a great experience with phones like Samsung and the Pixel 2 line; so if you're really into camera performance, perhaps watch a few more review videos of the V30 to see if camera/photo quality is to your liking.

I had one for a bit... Screen was good, battery life was excellent.
Camera was inconsistent. In good lightning it took great pictures, but in less than ideal conditions it really struggled... Due to its small sensor, it had to take longer exposures and rely too heavily on post processing. So static objects looked sterile, lacking texture, and faces were always either blurry or smudged... It was useless indoors and at night if I wanted a usable picture of my kids.

title: Pinch to Zoom not working on Youtube 18:9

thread.text: Last week Youtube was working fine on my phone. I could watch videos with black bars and fill the screen using pinch to zoom. All of a sudden yesterday it doesn't work. I always get black bars no matter what video I watch and pinch to zoom does nothing. I tried uninstalling and reinstalling the app multiple times and even factory reset my phone. I cleared cache also and nothing has worked. Anyone else having this problem?

replies.text: I have never been able to pinch to zoom with my V30+ unlocked

thread.text:
Welcome to Android Central! Works fine on my Pixel 2 XL. I did see another post about this kind of thing happening on a Samsung device recently, but that wasn't just on YouTube.
Does it persist in Safe Mode? https://support.t-mobile.com/docs/DOC-36664
Yeah it doesn't work in safe mode either. This is a very odd and annoying issue. It's not a total deal breaker but what good is an 18:9 screen if I can't fully use it.
Guess im going to have to just wait for the next youtube update. Should I take my phone back to T-Moblie? Ive only had it for 3 weeks.

My guess is that it has to do with the YouTube app itself (perhaps after a recent update), or maybe with Google Play Services, rather than the phone itself. It's doubtful that replacing the phone would help, although you could test a V30 on display at the T-Mobile store and see if the same thing happens there. Make sure the YouTube app is up to date on the display phone first.
In the meantime, send feedback to Google in the YouTube app's settings menu.

I have same problem.
My Huawei mate 10 Pro - not working pinch to zoom (18:9)
Brothers Huawei mate 10 pro - working pinch to zoom (18:9), same app version, same system version.
I don't understand....
I sent feedback to google. Just gonna have to wait until the next youtube update. Im not optimistic about it working. If that doesn't work im going to have to head back to T-Mobile to see whats up.

I'm seeing threads all over the place about this for different phones, like OnePlus and Pixel: https://forums.oneplus.net/threads/y...orking.794114/https://www.androidauthority.com/com...ng-help.52848/
Not working on my Honor 7x as well since the last YouTube update, tried everything but no success.
Is it just youtube, or do all videos play with black bars? I'm in the market for a new phone, but I watch a lot of video on it. Black bars would be a deal breaker for me.

I didn't really check any other videos because im mostly on Youtube but all of a sudden its been working for the last few days. No updates to youtube or my phone. Doesn't make any sense but whatever im happy. Love this phone now.

title: Does the V30 have a pinkish display?

thread.text: I saw a Pixel 2 XL the other day (made by LG) and I assume they use the same screens as the V30. The AMOLED screen looked super pinkish compared to the LCD on my V20, very ugly actually and the screen looked super dim and dark at max brightness. Should I be worried about the V30 display issues? I'm okay with the blue shift or whatever, just not a pink screen. Oh and the display models had screen burn in, my biggest fear. No one has any burn in yet?
uh, that sounds broken as hell. no, neither the v30 nor the pixel 2 xl have a pink display.

replies.text: How's the brightness compared to other phones? AMOLED screens are always dim to me.

thread.text:
V30 screen is gorgeous. I have no tint of any kind. Today after using Google maps and completing a route it asked me if everything went OK. The screen on which this all was presented looked so nice it was like a Galaxy screen. I took a screen shot of it.
Exceptionally beautiful display even next to a Samsung. Good blacks, gorgeous colors in stunning clarity and detail. It takes a special phone and or manufacturer to make it look this nice.
I'm guessing this was a display unit... A dim, pink AMOLED display is usually seen on display units that have been craving along near 24x7 at full brightness for several months straight.
The V30 display models are on all day, and so that is why they are experiencing some burn-in/screen issues. A friend of mine has the V30 and loves it! I would not worry about display issues.

title: Just a general question about size

thread.text:
I have a question for everyone. In my opinion the V30 is a very thin and lightweight phone even with a UAG case. How would users feel about a phone that is a little thicker making room for a higher capacity battery?
Looking forward to peoples opinions.
Thanks

replies.text: Got to be honest, battery life on the V30 is nothing short of phenomenal. I use it all day and have never made it past the 60% mark. I do have greenify installed.

thread.text: The V30 has pretty good battery life compared to its predecessors. I actually am slightly disappointed that the overall phone shrunk in width and height. I'd rather have had a larger screen with the same footprint as the V20.

Of all things to compromise on, battery isn't one of them, imo. In the age of gimmicky notches, emojis and multiple cameras, no one has ever complained about having big-sized batteries. To me, 4,000 mAh should be standard. I realize that optimization is also a factor with having good battery life, but why not have both? Because that's counterproductive to oems' bottom line, to have us spend asinine amounts of money every 6 months to two years, getting the "latest and greatest".
I get great battery life. Better than any other phones I have used.

I wish the phone was thicker and with a bigger battery. We don't need phones to be as thin as they are. The V30 has great battery life, but I still have to make sure it's charged when I leave work. At least now it doesn't need to be fully charged like my V20 did. Still, I'd love to be able to get through a full day of heavy use on a single charge. I can get through a full day of light to moderate use on a single charge, though, which has never been possible on any phone for me.
I hope the next flagship has at least 4000 mAh, but I would love options as high as 6000.
I get great battery life as well, but I'd love to see a 4000 mAh battery. I'd add 1-2 mm to the thickness for that.

My previous handset was the Droid Turbo, which had a large battery. I could easily get through 36 hours with it (48+ with light/light-moderate use). While the V30 has good battery life, 30 hours is about the max I've been able to get out of it, and that is with light usage on a good WiFi connection all day.
I'd love to see larger batteries become the standard, and it can be done without adding much bulk. However, as girl_interupted touched upon, OEMs won't do it because it may translate to a dip in sales. Most average consumers will get a new phone either because their OS gets bogged down or the battery life degrades to a frustrating level. A larger battery would obviously last longer and allow for a wider margin of entropy. Thus the consumer won't feel the need to upgrade as quickly as they once would.
OEMs know that as long as they provide a system that can get through 16 hours of use, consumers won't demand a larger battery because most don't consider lifespan.
It's not a fluke that OEMs are ditching removable batteries. There's a business reason for the move.

replies.text:
I believe the reason batteries aren't removable anymore is due to water resistance. Making the case easy to open up also makes it easier for water to enter. 
For me, even under moderate or heavy use over a 12 hour work day, my V30 has not dipped below 60%. It's a dream compared to every other smart phone I've owned. 
I was a big advocate for removable batteries, but the argument's starting to swing the other way. Now we have a smarter OS. Also if the battery does run low, you can use wireless charging or fast charging. We're not without options.

Water resistance is the convenient marketing angle for sealing in batteries.
And not arguing charging abilities, but pointing out what is done once the battery won't hold a good charge.

Hi can anyone tell me if they are getting any haptic feedback when pressing the buttons on their keyboard?
I didn't even notice that I don't have it until I went to Target and used a Galaxy Note 8 and felt how great it felt o know you hit the button, giving it an almost real button feel. 
Since getting my LG v30 I've literally just been touching glass with no feedback whatsoever and I have all the settings turned on for vibration upon press and I can't seem to get it working on LG keyboard, Gboard or Grammarly keyboard. All vibration settings are turned on it seems.

On my V30, the generic settings are at
settings > sound > more > vibrate on tap
Vibrate and sound settings for each keyboard will be within each keyboard's settings app.
LG: in the "more" grouping
Gboard: in the "preferences" grouping
swiftkey: typing > sound 
I have not tried the various combinations of sound and/or vibrations since the first thing I did was turn off all of it.

I'm thinking about trading in my LG G5, and going with the V30. I really want a great camera on my next phone. One thing I don't understand is the V30 camera reviews. Many of them seem to have the V30 performing better than the Galaxy phones, and some of course prefer the S8's. Many of the users on here seem to say that the auto mode is just ok, but when I look at posted photo's, I personally think many of them look great. I looked at photo's on the S9's thread, and some actually seem out of focus, so all of this info leaves me a little confused about which is best. 
One of my peeves about the G5, is taking a photo indoors, any light coming in through a window or from a T.V. screen, seems to cause focus problems on the subject and really wash out the whole photo, where my sons Note 8 handles those situations a lot better.
I guess I am asking, is the V30's camera a huge upgrade over the G5, and is it on par or even better than the S8's camera?

I had the G4, and I've said often, since then, each camera I have tried (V20, V30) has been a downgrade. I am not sure what hardware or software exactly caused this, but I've never been able to get the quality I did with the G4.
Like most camera phones out there today, the camera does function great in good lighting or with stationary objects, but even in good lighting, with a object even slightly in motion, I'll get blur in some part of the photo. An example I can give is a guy playing a guitar. Most of the photo will be amazing looking and crystal clear, but the strumming hand will always show up blurry, every time. Just a bit of a bummer.
As always...these are just my own opinions.
Thanks, I also had a G4, and thought maybe it was just me, but I always said that camera was better than the G5.

Yes, the G4 had a great camera system.
I like the V30 camera, but I always have low expectations for any phone camera. While other phone cameras may be better, the V30 camera in auto mode does fine by me; I have no problems dropping into manual mode to get better images. Of course, if I want a great shot then I will grab one of my DSLRs.
All phone cameras seem to suffer from the same bad marketing decisions: lots of megapixels on a tiny sensor is a bad thing for image quality.

It's mind boggling. I watch the review videos, and I don't know if they are done by so called fanboys, or if they are biased, but they seem to be all over the place. I do think my sons note 8 takes nicer shots than my G5, but I'm really not crazy about the curved screens of the Samsungs. They just seem annoying. But if the V30 isn't going to produce much better pics than my G5, it may not really be worth the price of the upgrade.

thread.text:

replies.text: There's no way BT will sound better than the Quad Dac, let alone a wired connection period.

How well something sounds to a given person is subjective. How well the sound measures isn't. AFAIK, Bluetooth doesn't measure better than wired audio but with use of an EQ it may actually sound better than un-EQ'd wired cans. It just depends on the person's prefs. Given the same amount or lack thereof of EQ wired should...should sound better but it may not even be a difference some would notice.
If you have to use an EQ then that means you aren't getting good sound. And AFAIK, EQ settings etc don't apply for a BT connection.

I've read in audio forums from folks that agree with you. I tend to listen to my audio rig with the sound unmolested by tone controls and EQ but the UHQ Upscaler on my Note 8 doesn't sound bad at all to me. In fact I find it rather pleasant and I'm not normally into smoke and mirrors.

Not what I was saying, I meant that Samsung over Bluetooth offers better audio quality (imo) than the v30 over Bluetooth.
On Bluetooth I find that all eq does on the v30 is ruin the sound (again just imo) similar on the pixel too as soon as you turn on eq it just sounds horrible, whereas on the Samsung I can keep it pretty flat and just boost the bass slightly without otherwise affecting the rest of the sound.

thread.text: The V30's quad ESS DAC and very clean, variable power (and auto-selecting) amp are awesome, but one point that hasn't been discussed yet is potentially even more important for mobile (i.e., earbud/IEM) use: Samsung's phones tend to have a fairly high output impedance (~5 Ohm), which skews the frequency response. A lot of sensitive IEMs like the SE846 sound like a muddy mess out of a Samsung phone. I too would to see Samsung fix this, because in every other respect their phones are awesome. But so far LG are (and continue to be, even with the release of the S9) far ahead in terms of wired audio output.
I so want to get a V30 and keep it for a week or two to do a back-to-back vs. my iPhone X, Mate 9, and Note 8. Gotta try to have a little discipline though.

The DAC's that support the current line of mobile processor's are pretty good. The Samsung update obviously updated the software not the hardware, therefore it is software tricks(for lack of a better word). The V20 is not exactly the same spec as the V30. Out of the many DAP's I have I really do enjoy the V30 sound quality. Bluetooth quality is good with the V30 but it is Bluetooth. I do not think the discussion of the sq can be wireless focused when you only achieve the benefit of the quad DAC through the headphone jack.

Hi MA2GA28... See below for my Q&A to RINGKE.
'Q' to RINGKE: I got my LG V30 Phone Case Ringke [FUSION] Crystal Clear today. Is the 'back film' included in your packaging to be applied to my phone or the exterior of the Fusion case itself? I foresee attaching it to the exterior of the Fusion case itself to be dust/dirt magnet. Thank you.
'A' from RINGKE: Thank you for contacting Ringke. Please be informed the protective film is designed to be installed directly on the back of the device to help prevent any possible "rainbow" effects.

I actually took the phone out and used it careless at home. Gad, I forgot how lovely this phone is to hold. I had heard it feels cheap and light. No way this thing is gorgeous, has so.e heft to it and just feels great in the hand. 
Anyone know of if any super light weight faux leather cases are available for this phone like we're once made by Invellop for Galaxy S4?

I have the Unicorn Beetle Pro and it's a sturdy case. It adds just enough weight to improve the feel of the phone as well.

If you don't use a Qi charger then this case can't be beat. Mine came in today and I'm very happy with it so far. It is only about $10 and has a metal plate integrated into the back that doesn't add any bulk and won't scratch the glass on the back. The plate is inside the case when they poured the mold I guess. This makes it great for those newer magnet car mounts. It isn't cheap and flexible like most rubbery TPU cases. It feels slightly more rigid than those. Almost like 80% solid plastic / 20% TPU rubber. Super thin so it doesn't add bulk and has a matte texture for better grip. The "carbon fiber" design looks very authentic and is textured like the real thing. Not sure it would survive on a major drop (4 feet plus), but then again I don't think any slim case is expected to. That's why they make those bulky rugged cases. I got mine on Amazon. Search for TJS Ultra Slim Fit LG V30 Case.

Just bought the "AModern" Slim Case for V30
Got it yesterday. Phone fits fine. Looks great. I'm not sure if I'll be getting used to the handling of the side flip case, but we'll see.

I think I've owned or tried most of the cases listed in this thread. When I first got my V30, I ordered a bunch of different clear TPU cases, searching for the thinnest possible. Curiously, most of them were the exact-same product, just with different branding. Most of them were pretty thick, which adds to the width of the phone.
What I wanted was a very thin TPU case - the sort of case that's so thin you don't know it's there. I just want protection from scratches and minor drops - I don't plan on throwing my phone from tall buildings, so don't want anything bulky. I found a case like this for my S8 (made by Casearmy), but was never able to find one for the V30. The best clear TPU case I found was by Turtle Armor, but it's still much thicker than the TPU case I had for my S8. The V30 is already a bit wider than I'd like when using one-handed; I'm not into plus-sized phones. 
So I eventually gave up with the case idea and looked at the wraps/skins available. Most of the skins available (IQ Shield, Clear Coat, etc.) are poorly designed, with separate little individual pieces that stick all the way around the edges. But the PhantomSkinz skin for the V30 is one piece that wraps around the sides and perfectly fits over even the tiniest holes for the speaker grills and two mics. It adds some grip and scratch protection, but no bulk :-)

title: Love my V30 + but a couple of things are niggling

thread.text:

Everything seemed to be working ok, but I cannot use the LG Smart View, as there is no option in the drop down country menu, for the United Kingdom? All of the countries listed are in and around Asia. Can this be rectified at all? 
The second thing, the smart lock has decided to stop working. I can go through the process of location, high accuracy, it finds my address, I check it, save it, then go back a page and it says, nothing set, smart setting turned off. It was working fine, up to today, now it will not play ball.
Any advice appreciated - many thanks

That's very strange, you may try in about phone update LG apps to see if maybe smart lock gets updated and it may fix the issue. If not, you may consider using lg backup to back all your data up yo an sd card and doing a factory reset.

thread.text: Glad to hear it!

I'm probably leaning toward picking up the V30 in May. As of this moment, it seems like it ticks all the boxes for what I look for in a phone. I appreciate the MIL SPEC rating, as I tend to be clumsy, lol. I also like the IP68 waterproofing, and of course, the quad DAC, which is one of the bigger selling points to me as a music lover.
That being said, how much storage is availavle to the user on both the 64 GB and 128 GB variants? With a 3,300 mAh battery, what can I realistically expect in terms of battery life SOT and standby time? Being a lighter user, I don't do gaming, nor do I take anything more than the occasional point-and-shoot photo. All I do is talk, text, browse the web, stream my music on GPM, watch YouTube videos and forum. Great standby is a must.
Also, I'm hoping any niggling issues have been addressed regarding screen uniformity in later batches? Can anyone please confirm or deny this? I know LG is having its issues lately, but as much as they're pretty phones, something about Samsung scares me. Feedback is appreciated.

replies.text:
Insane standby battery, when on mid-level battery saver. Great battery on standby without battery saver. Your haptic feedback wont work though on mid-level battery saver. So I switch battery saver on while at work since i dint use phone much there. Leave work with 80% then switch off battery saver to have haptics. 
Get a couple wireless charging pads to leave around the house or at work. Slap the v30 on those occasionally and you wont even need to bring your fast charger everywhere you go like I did with Samsung. 
Gorgeous screen too. Absolutely zero issues with screen or tint or anything. Lovely very high-end screen. The quad DAC is exactly what its cracked up to be. Nutty.
Thanks for the info, great to know. Do you have the 64 GB or 128? I don't have a lot of apps installed, but I figure 128 GB is good to have. How many GB do you have available to you?

title: Cheap/free way to add oleophobic coating back

thread.text: Add a drop of hair conditioner and rub it in dry with a microfiber cloth. Should resist oil and fingerprints and bring back smoothness. Also works on tables and other surfaces. Always test it out first just incase. I have the Suave Coconut Conditioner from Walmart that I used.

replies.text: Okay, so I just tried it with a small dot of Head & Shoulder conditioner and wow! That's amazing. Thank you! Where did you come across that trick?

thread.text:
Received my new V30+ on Thursday. Set about installing the tempered glass screen protector i had pre-purchased and noticed a bubble in the top right quadrant. I couldn't smooth it out though. I thought maybe the screen protector was bad, but I removed it and it actually was fine. What I noticed is that screen has a valley over an inch long and because of it, he screen protector won't sit flat on the glass causing thay section to look like there is an air bubble underneath. I hit up T-Mobile and they told me I can return it for a regular V30 because they have no more V30+s available to them.
So I'm wondering if this might be because of LG's strategy with the V30S which is said to also have 128GB of storage but also 6GB of ram. I want this phone, but I also want to be able to protect it. I had a V20 and I'm pretty careful with my phones, but I did not immediately put a screen protector on it and ended up with a tiny phantom chip in the screen that was almost unnoticeable except for when your finger ran across it.
I already registered for the 2 year V30 promise so I guess I'm protected in that manner, but I wanted to see what everyone else's thoughts were. Bear in mind, I've had the Optimus G, G3, G4 and 2 V20s(different carriers). So I have no qualms with LG in general.
Oh, and my wife's V30+ came with a stripe of bad pixels down the screen (stuck white) so there's that I suppose, LOL. She got hers on Tuesday so I will be having her register with LG quick, fast, and in a hurry as well.

replies.text:
The V30 was not designed to have a screen protector and LG isn't really responsible for anything in regards to 3rd party accessories. Some phones have small defects on the glass, such as warping and uneven surfaces. It's really hard to make a curved glass phone 100% flawless so there will be some slight warping in the glass, therefore glass screen protectors may not adhere correctly. Apple is smart and designed their phones to accept tempered glass screen protectors (probably because they know they get royalty fees from 3rd party manufacturers), and might be the only thing I like about Apple's design.
BTW I had 2 V20s and the first one didn't allow a glass protector to fully adhere but the 2nd one adhered 100%.

title: Exchange using up battery - what is this?

thread.text:
On Verizon and this am my phone updated to Oreo.
But now there is an icon in the upper ‘tray’ that Exchange using battery. Googled this but did not seem to find anything of recent.
I do not use Outlook, but do use Gmail. 
Can I disable or uninstall the Exchange if the phone lets me?

replies.text:
Open the Settings app
Press”Apps and notifications”
Press”All apps”
Press the three-dot menu in the top right
Press “Show system”
Scroll down and press “Android System”
Press “App notifications”
Switch the toggle next to “Apps using battery”
That will turn off the notification, but I don't have Exchange downloaded. ( Not in all apps)

thread.text: Just wondering if anyone has some awesome custom screen settings they are using and would like to share them and what they feelnthe benefit is. No judgment. Everyone likes what they like. I'd go 1st but so far, I haven't noticed much of a difference between the existing presets so maybe I'm not the best person to start it off, LOL.

I just use themes from the LG Smart world and I set up my Go Weather Widget and Nova settings to match. I back up Nova settings based on what theme I'm using. 
I keep the home screen clutter free and I have three dock pages for most of what I use.

On my V30, I use the factory launcher, "home & app drawer".
The theme is the default LG theme.
Lock screen and home screen are using two beach volleyball photos I took (summer, fairly bright).
I have the "comfort view" set to the schedule 6pm to 6am (reduces blue light).
I have the "screen color" set to best-for-pictures, which seems a bit warmer than the "normal" setting.
I use the "auto brightness". Depending on what I am watching (pictures/movies), I may adjust the brightness up a little. I have not noticed any problems in bright sunlight yet, but winters in Seattle tend to be rather cloudy.
In the Developer settings:
Show touches = on. It can help to see where my fat fingers are registering.
window animation scale = 0.5x (speeds up the animation)
transition animation scale = 0.5x (speeds up the animation)
Is it really not that great?
The answer depends on what you are comparing it to, and on what you intend to do with the resulting pictures.

So I went into a local AT&T store yesterday to check out the new S9+. Of course, being a fan of music, I immediately plugged my 32 ohm impedance earbuds into the headphone jack. I will say that it sounded really loud for being a good three to four notches from max volume. Also, toggling on Dolby Atmos definitely makes a difference. 
Even so, the prospect of that quad DAC is still making me consider the V30+ or V30S. The thing is, when I tested my earbuds on the V30, it made no difference to the sound whether the DAC was toggled on or off. I have seen a demo, however, where the DAC does get triggered with headphones of 50+ impedance, and it makes quite a difference.
I have a few questions, especially for those that have prior experience with HTC BoomSound-enabled phones as well. 
First, when I tested my earbuds on an HTC, the sound was fantastic, where you could almost hear every instrument individually, yet it sounds full and rich, with just enough punch of bass, with no distortion at max volume. Would you say that headphone audio from the V30 is similar, on-par, or superior to BoomSound?
Second, I consider myself a light user. I don't do anything graphic intensive like gaming, nor am I into photography, other than the occasional point-and-shoot. All I do is talk, text, stream my music, watch YouTube and forum. What kind of battery life (and standby time) can I expect with the V30?
Third, how is the brightness of the screen in sunlight? Would I have to squint, cup my hand over the screen, or find shade to be able to see it?
Fourth, how much storage is available to the user from both the 64 and 128 GB storage options? I currently have 53 GB free on my 64 GB Nexus 6P, which is plenty, but the V30 has more features and preinstalled apps.
I want to upgrade at some point, but I don't take spending $1,000+ dollars when all is said and done likely. The way I see it, my options are either the upcoming Note 9, V30 (or V40, depending on what this supposed "Judy" phone is), the HTC U12, or whatever Huawei has coming later this year. Anyway, your feedback is appreciated.

title: Some advice from all you V30 owners, please

thread.text:
I've had the Note 5 with AT&T for a year and a half now and I'm starting to desire an upgrade. I was originally thinking of upgrading to the S8 but not since Samsung forced their curved screen on all of us. Not really a fan of curved screens. I was hoping the Note 8 would be awesome, but unfortunately it's just a repackaged S8 with a pen.
I've had my eye on the V30 since it was first announced and the phone has intrigued me. 
So ... I've read a ton of reviews, watched some videos, but now I want to hear from all you V30 owners - is this really a decent contender to upgrade to from my Note 5?
I thank all of you ahead of time for any input you give me.

replies.text:
Im a long time samsung user, i switched to v30 for it's amazing DAC, and because the form of new Note didnt appeal to me. 
Honestly the biggest changes for me were:
Adjusting to the less saturated screen. Samsung is hard to beat in screen beauty. But I'm now used to the LG screen, and am noticing certain small details that look better on a less saturated screen. For example certain logos on YouTube videos, for instance the CG Bros logo, on the short CGI films that CG Bros makes is ultra detailed. Another logo that has concentric circles in it that get smaller the closer they get to the center is entirely visible even down to the last inner lines. It's quite amazing. 
The battery life is greatly improved going from samsung to v30+. It's like night and day. With samsung you need apps and full time babysitting of the battery, with v30+ you dont even need to look at battery anymore. I come home after 12 hours work day of light use except when on breaks, with 80% percent battery.
The headphone jack on this and other LG devices is without question the best of any smartphone I'm told. It sure sounds like it.
Imo the camera on Samsung devices was better because I could just point and shoot on automatic mode and gets stunning pictures almost every time and I can't get good pictures really at all with the v30 but I have seen many many photos that people have taken with the v30 that are stunning so it looks like I just don't know how to do it yet.

I think it's a very good replacement to the aging Note 5. I would say the camera quality is similar but it includes a useful wide angle you'll find yourself using in certain situations. The microphone is MUCH better, with 3 microphones at different angles, it's great for recording video at concerts. RAM management and battery is much more efficient with SD 835 + LG's optimized OS. The AMOLED screen might not beat Samsung's but it shouldn't matter too much. The phone's form factor is much lighter and comfortable than the old and clunky Note 5. You won't get an S Pen but there's some built in note taking apps with the doodle feature. Coming from the Note 5, you'll like it.

title: Make sure you're getting the most from your HiFi DAC!

thread.text:
Hi all  I recently purchased the V30+ and discovered something that I think is important to share with other users. I have no way of knowing if this problem is unique to my set up, but regardless it's some food for thought.
I noticed that the quality of my audio and it's volume was often inconsistent. For info I use Sony WH1000x Mk2 and obviously connect to the V30+ headphone jack and ensure the HiFi DAC is on. Some times when i connected and powered up my headphones I would get amazing audio and a powerful sound, not able to go above 60 volume without hurting my ears. Other times the sound would be somewhat lacklustre and I would have to go to 75 volume to even come close to the previous. 
After some basic process of elimination I discovered that it was due to the sequence that I connect my headphones. If I connect the cable to my headphones first and then the V30+ I get the sub par sound, however if I connect the cable to the V30+ FIRST and then connect into the Sonys, I get the full HiFi experience.
In the end I do not know why this is. As I said, perhaps it is a problem unique to my gear, but nonetheless if you have a V30+ I would recommend comparing the audio you get out of it using the above method. 
Peace!

replies.text: I don't think you're getting full output that way. When I did what you describe I got the external device setting which is the second output.
How do you know you're getting the external device setting? And what do you mean by second output?

There are 3 output levels
Normal
External
High impedance
You method triggers external for plugging into a aux jack like your car. You can see the level if you open the hifi sound setting.

thread.text: More than likely, it's the astronomical impendence caused by the open circuit of not having the headphones connected to the cable. Good trick though.

replies.text: Yeah I've been looking in to this a little more and it seems like it's actually a pretty well established trick to get more impedence out of the unit. This thread talks about normal, aux and high impedence settings that are triggered depending on what is connected.https://www.head-fi.org/threads/lg-v30.858933/page-117

thread.text: I think my last post may have been deleted because it contained a link to another forum -my bad. But yeah it turns out that the LG detects the impedence of the headphones you connect and chooses from HiFi, AUX or High Impedence (50ohm+)setting. A lot of people are finding that their headphones don't trigger anything above normal HiFi and subsequently they aren't getting enough juice to drive their headphones properly. My WH1000x are 46ohm, so just shy of triggering the High Impedence setting.

I am a reviewer on Head-Fi and my own blog...I just want to say all you have to do is plug your cable first always then attack IEM or HP and it automatically goes into "aux" mode. If you have the T-Mobile variant you can download HiFI Status from the app store and it will show you what mode you are in. I love the V30 sound but I always plug the cable in solely first
audiorabbithole.com

title: LG V30 Random Reboot (Caused by Bluetooth?)

thread.text:
Hi - My first post here.
I replaced iPhone 6 Plus with LG V30. The first V30 had low GPS signal issue; it can't tell me where I am at while driving around washington D.C. area. Any, I haven't noticed the GPS issue with the replacement phone but I am experiencing random reboot issue and audio .5 to 3.5 seconds audio lag over bluetooth when watching video; like Netflix and Youtube.
Random Reboot - This happended 2-4 times a day while I was on vacation in Pismo Beach and using the phone heavily watching Netflix over bluetooth. Bluetoot to my 2014 Honda Odyssey had 3.5 seconds audio lag. Strangely bluetooth to portable speaker didn't have the audio lag. 
Audio Lag - experiencing it on both my 2016 BMW and 2014 Honda Odyssey. On the BMW, it is about 1 second lag. I tried to clear cache and deleted all BT devices and try to reconnect to my BMW and the phone rebooted.
Each time it reboots, it seems to be related to Bluetooth but there may have been one occasion where it was related to Wifi connection.
Anyone experiencing reboot or BT audio lag?

replies.text:
Most of the Bluetooth issues have been fixed with latest patches. I had some static issues here & there plus the occasional Track info not showing up on my car center console. It's pure perfection running the latest 20f Oreo update. It all depends on when your carrier decides to roll out the update.
As for the audio lag, that's to be expected when you're missing any codecs to help with the latency. The phone does come with an AptX codec to deal with the latency issues. You can from seconds to below 40 milliseconds (with such a low latency, you won't notice the lag). You also need to make sure your BT reciever also has the matching codec (which might be the case with your speaker). You could always buy an AUX BT receiver with the codec & simply plug it in your car stereo.
So I need to wait on Oreo for the bluetooth issues to be fixed? I am wondering if the latest tmobile update addresses the bluetooth issues. The latest build is H93210c.

thread.text: I did not experience these. I did have bluetooth issues with the two V30s I tried. Specifically, there was a lot of static on phone calls made using bluetooth and my car's speakers. Using the bluetooth for anything else (music and podcasts were unaffected, as were phonecalls made without bluetooth.

Just an update. The Bluetooth audio lag is due to the codec and it is probably because the Bluetooth version on the BMW and Honda. I confirmed that using a Bluetooh adapter that support AptX LL; the lag is barely noticeable.
However, my phone still randomly reboots and it is only when I am connected to Bluetooth in the car. Pretty annoying to have the phone reboot during a conference call or in the middle of a game.

title: Tidal Now Streams in Masters (MQA) on the V30!

thread.text:
Saw this as the description of the Tidal update that I got last night. This change is apparently for the V30 only.
So, I opened my Tidal app, played a song that I know is Masters (MQA) and it still showed streaming in only 'HiFi.'
I opened the settings (top right corner when you select 'My Collection' at the bottom right) then selected 'Streaming' and under WiFi switched that selection from 'HiFi' to 'Master.'
Played the song again, and it still showed as playing in only 'HiFi' mode.
Closed the Tidal app and re-opened it. Played that same song again and YES! the big blue 'Master' symbol shows up near the bottom of the screen!!
There are 2 steps in decoding an MQA encoded song. First is "Unfolding," which can be done in the player software or in an MQA capable DAC, and the second step is "Rendering" which can only be done in an MQA capable DAC. Some MQA capable DACs will do both steps, and some MQA capable DACs will only do the Rendering step. You have to find out from the specs of the DAC if it does both steps or only the Rendering.
My understanding is that the desktop (PC or MAC) Tidal app does the Unfolding step within its own software. But, I don't have any info as to whether or not the new V30 version of the Tidal app does the unfolding inside itself. Will try to find out.

I just wanted to follow up to my original post here. After having owned both phones now, I can say the Pixel 2 XL does not exhibit this stuttering/lagginess effect when scrolling long articles or timelines. To clarify, the V30 is blazingly quick when opening apps or switching between apps, but it's distractingly frustrating when using some apps such as Plume for Twitter or even when scrolling Applications in the Settings menu. Google must be doing some additional optimization of the OS to improve the performance because spec wise, both the V30 and the Pixel 2 appear to be identical. I've noticed the same stuttering on my girlfriend's Galaxy S8, so LG is not alone. 
I can say the same thing for the cameras. The camera specs of the V30 appear to be equal or even superior to the Pixel 2, yet the Pixel 2 photos are simply stunning compared to the photos from the V30, which were surprisingly disappointing (especially indoors). Whatever optimization Google is doing with their HDR+ processing makes a significant difference.
Reluctantly, I returned the V30 for the Pixel 2 XL. I really liked the size and feel of the hardware of the V30 and the added features of the headphone jack and wireless charging. But I just became increasingly frustrated with the stuttering within apps and the poor low light photos. The Pixel 2 XL is noticeably larger than the V30 and bezels are clunkier, which is disappointing. I don't use headphones that often, so I'm okay with out the headphone jack. And I may not need the wireless charging capability as the battery life of the Pixel 2 XL has been remarkable so far where I haven't needed to top up during the day yet with it (currently over 4 hours SOT with 42% battery life left).
Ultimately, neither phone is perfect, but they're both pretty damn good in their own ways. I think it comes down to which features are more important to each buyer. Not a bad problem to have!

In that case, I feel like the phone is deliberately 'waiting' to see if you want to just launch or use a shortcut.
That said, I disable sound effects or special effects for everything unnecessary and I've done this for every phone I've owned.
I change my screen resolution as well if I'm not doing anything related to graphics and finally, on my end, WI-fi is terrible where I live (location issue not a phone issue) and so I often turn it off if reception is bad. Cellular is perfectly fine.
Some ideas that may have already been explored: 
Maximum Battery Saver and see if anything improves. Clear cache and data for unused apps. Use the native cleaning app. Once you do that, reboot. Bad reception can muck things up - especially if you have auto-upload on for things like saved pictures, etc. Slow microSD = slower access to its content.
Disclaimer: I own an older LG tablet which worked for my productivity needs and had to manage with less than stellar specs. In my experience, it's usually outside apps still running in the background or some kind of special effects that I didn't need that caused laggy episodes.
