title: Lowering resolution - how much does it boost graphics performance?

thread.text: Hi, has anyone experienced faster performance from graphics intensive apps by lowering the screen resolution in the settings menu? Just wondering how much of a difference this will make to graphics performance.
I reduce the resolution on games to 1080p, and it seems to help. I leave it on max for the interface, it didn't seem to really effect battery life just browsing on the phone.

On other LG devices (G5, G6) people were eliminating or turning off Quickmemo+ to save battery life.(myself included) 
I'm just curious to see if anyone still does this with their V30?
I don't use Quickmemo+ on my V30, but I also don't have it disabled.

For me, I own an LG Android tablet that comes with a stylus and so for me, QM+ has become something of an essential because it's a quick native way to take notes without adding more apps.
Click, write or type and/or post a picture, add to Home, done. When note becomes irrelevant, remove. If there are multiple notes, I can just slide to scroll through them all.
Now that I have a V30 (QM+ is actually a reason I chose LG), it never occurred to me to turn it off because I actually use it.
Then again, after all this time, I never realized it could save that much battery, either!
I have fairly heavy usage on that tablet because I play games a lot on it and so I never figured QM+ used enough battery to warrant disabling. If anything, it's all of my apps and their unneeded background activities that needed throttling.
Is QM+ being disabled because people aren't using it and so it's an unnecessary app or is QM+ a huge battery drain?

I find QM+ a useful app, so I keep it enabled.
I don't see why it would be running when not in use; it is not that kind of app.
I don't think anyone ever explained how or why it was draining their battery. Just that it was on previous model LGs.

It doesn't look like you can disable quickmemo+ without a package disabler app. I could only force stop it using the application manager. It did report it had used 7% battery since last charge. I don't use it, so I don't know why it would use so much battery.

replies.text: What app are you using that reported it?
I just went into the application manager and selected quickmemo+. battery use is toward the bottom.

Thanks for the instructions!
I did the same and I see what you mean. Unfortunately, I don't think it's 'just' QuickMemo+ that's to blame.
When I checked, I was at 3% (but I also actually use the app and have 2 memos posted on my screens) and then when I went to check other apps and processes, I realized that there were several Android processes running that were all using the same amount of battery. This also includes Google Play and anything related to Google Play.
So now I'm really confused. Is this 3% for just one process? Or is this 3% including every single one of those 3% processes?
I hope I'm making sense.
Incidentally, I discovered that my QM+ app comes with an Uninstall option! Does yours and have you tried it? I'm afraid to test it out because I don't know how easy it will be to get the app back.

Are you having problems running out of battery? For me, battery life is so good, I don't need to worry about any stats. I leave Bluetooth and wireless always on. Don't use any battery saving apps (the ones on the phone or 3rd party apps).

Not at all - even without Battery Saver! 
I've got fantastic battery life so I'm not particularly concerned about QM+ using battery.
The fact that it came attached to so many processes was just a little surorising is all!

I get what you mean. When you click on the battery % under the QM+ it shows the battery usage for "System". It probably is for multiple services. I do not have the uninstall option, just force stop & disable is greyed out. I'm on verizon, what about you?

I'm on T-Mobile. 
Under Google Services and Connected apps, I have QM+ listed because it backs up my notes to Google Drive.
Is yours listed there, too?
Yes, it was listed there. I hit disconnect. Hopefully that doesn't mess anything up.

title: Still can't decide between V30 and Samsung S8+ anyone on here tired both?

thread.text: Been comparing both the AT&T V30 AND AT&T S8+, reading reviews, watching YouTube videos, and it seems like the opinions are split almost 50/50 on these 2 phones. Anyone on here actually owned both or used both phones? I know I can swap them out within the 14 day period, just was looking for opinions from regular users not just reviews from Android sites. Thanks.

replies.text: I tried both at T-mobile. They're both top notch Android devices. The only differences between the 2, is that the s8+ has a bigger screen. Of course that also makes the phone bigger. The reason I bought the V30 was because of the dac, and because the V30 is so much more ergonomic in the hand. Light too.

I had the S8+ and I was annoyed by it so much I immediately sold it within a week. The fingerprint scanner you will NOT get used to, it's extremely annoying. The shape is very weird too, it's freakishly long and skinny, so when watching a video via landscape mode, the screen looks small (narrow display + YouTube black bars from aspect ratio). It feels more like a 5.4 inch phone really. And the curves are just too much... phantom touches and trying to put a screen protector on that thing you're going to go crazy. On the positive side, it is an excellent phone. The camera shutter speed is instantaneous and the 8MP selfie looks very nice. However, I could not see myself using it long term because of the annoying shape and design so I bought a V20 AGAIN.
Oh yeah and Touch Wiz sucks, uses too much RAM. Probably will slow down over time just like every other Samsung. I enjoy the LG OS much better, very fast and absolutely no hiccups even years later. Plus the tap to wake makes life easier. BTW I'm not a Samsung hater, I still own a Samsung laptop which still rocks. But phones and TV's I'm starting to question their longevity (S6 phone battery died too soon, Samsung TV died within 2 years).

thread.text: Maybe it would help to know what phones you've used prior, so we can also see what things you might miss if you go either way.
I own the S8 and I can confirm its display is the best ever.

replies.text: Thanks, but how well does it work as a Phone, cell signal, call quality, battery life? Which carrier are you using it on?

This is one question that I never see asked or answered in any of the reviews. Cell signal is a huge determining factor for me. I've had phones that work great in fringe areas, and then another wouldn't even get service in that same spot. I wish they would do more reviews on signal strength.

Yes you are correct. It appears that everyone in the technology field has totally forgotten that these things we spend good money on are called Smart PHONES! First and foremost the darn thing needs to work reliability as....... Surprise... A Phone. I sometimes think I'm the only person that actually depends on it as a phone first, then after that almost any priced phone will take pictures, check emails, play games. But if your phone has no signal and you stuck someplace alone, well I guess you can take pretty pictures of the place you stuck abandoned at

Nobody has forgotten about anything. Cell reception is completely dependant on your location. So how the hell is some reviewer supposed to comment on the cell reception that you may or may not experience? What's the point? Choose your carrier, then chose your phone.

There are ways to compare a cell phone's signal strength in the exact area the person testing the phone is at on all networks that the phone is capable of. Using a calibrated cellular RF signal (read in db) meter and compare that to what the phone is actually receiving. Example : cell phone A and cell phone B are sitting stationary in a known location that is putting out a known signal of -72 db on carrier X, phone A is reading an incoming signal of say -112 for example, and phone B is reading -74 that would mean that phone A has either a poor antenna, poor antenna placement, or poor radio software. I know this is all beyond the spectrum of a phone reviewer and should be the responsibility of the manufacturer. But there are phones out there with poor antenna placement, poorly made antennas, and / or mismatched baseband radio software.
I guess being an engineer makes me a little OCD about these things

I definitely agree with you! I've noticed signal strength differs for me in specific areas depending on which phone I use. Same carrier, same place, different phone... So signal strength and reliability are important!
I agree, I have had the S8+ and the V20 and they both had a so-so signal. Which is why I am now trying the V30, so far it has been pretty good! It is a lot smoother than the V20!

thread.text: LG V20, (gave it to my daughter to replace a broken phone) almost every Google Nexus, HTC M8, u11, Samsung, Note 2, S6 Active and my company phone is a plain S7. Wasn't crazy about the Nexus 4, or the M8. Other than that, my main priorities on any phone these days are cell signal, call quality, and battery life. That's about it. For my purposes as long as the camera takes pictures that are not terrible, or require messing around with a bunch of settings I'm happy. Don't really care about photographer quality pictures, just as long as there good enough to email for parts identification and readable writing on the images. I know there's plenty of low priced mid tier phones but I also need wifi calling to work so it has to be an AT&T branded phone.

I am no American, so I don't know what brands AT&T are offering, but the things you demand from a smartphone are IMHO something most phones can do well. So it might be worth testing something like, say, the Moto G5Plus or so. High quality budget phones are normally way enough for most demands.
But if it must be Samsung S8+ or the LG V30 I am a bit biased, being an ex Samsung user who had a lot of troubles with the phone. IP68, MIL-STD 810G, quick/wireless charging ... all of that seems very cool and are the reason I decided for this phone and not for the Huawei Mate 10 Pro, which was the other interesting option for me.
So as always: this is just my 2 Euro-cents.

Went to an AT&T store today played with the V30, Note 8, and S8+, I really have no need for the Note at all, and I can't get over the edge thing on the S8, I thought Samsung improved on the edge after the S7 edge but it's the same, the V30 is almost like a flat screen, the little bit of curve it has is not bad at all. I found the same problem on the Samsungs that I found on the S7 Edge, keep hitting things randomly by just hitting the edge with your palm. The screen on the V30 looks great in person, actually the S8 was uneven looking on a totally white background. And after owning the V20 the phone just felt more familiar to me. So the V30 it is. Thank you all for the responses.

I used both phones. In fact I used the GS8, Note 8, V30 and GS8+. The V30 is an excellent phone. While I am partial to LG (having had much better luck with them than Samsung), I ended up on the GS8+. Although the form factor and location of the fingerprint sensor are inconvenient, I have adjusted this time. As for the V30, every feature seemed on par with the Samsung galaxies. In fact I would say I preferred it because of the more convenient location of the fingerprint sensor, camera options (e.g., widescreen shots), knock code (something so simple, but I absolutely love it), voice unlock and face unlock. It was great having ALL those options available at the same time (with Samsung, you cannot use face unlock AND iris recognition at the same time). Battery life for the V30 was fantastic. The color shift when looking at the display was there, but: 1) it's there with the Samsung phones too and 2) I didn't notice it after a while. Yes, the display is a notch below Samsung. But honestly, I didn't notice. When staring at it, I just thought it was fantastic. The V30 camera is excellent. 
So why did I choose the GS8+? I had bluetooth problems with both V30s I used. I experienced static during calls (yeah, I still use my phone for calls. Weird, I know). This was not an issue with any other phone I used this year (I also used the G6 and the Samsungs I list above). When my second V30 had the same problem and I could only find one other person on line reporting the issue, I realized it was likely a compatibility issue with my car's bluetooth audio. Although the static issue seems unique to me, it seems to be one that I will continue to experience with the V30, so I decided against a third attempt at the phone. That being said, the V30 is an outstanding phone. As is the S8+ (and I can deactivate Bixby. Soo thrilled at that). But if bluetooth were not an issue, I would be the proud owner of a V30.

thread.text:
I have tried both. I recommend the V30 for the following reasons:
V30 has a more comfortable feel, curves aren't too much therefore using and holding the phone feels better and natural. Fingerprint scanner is more naturally placed in the center VS somewhere far where it's hard to reach. The V30 screen looks bigger because it's not actually super skinny and narrow like the S8+. The S8+ indeed has a better single camera, both front and rear. However, the V30 has a 16MP so when you zoom/crop, you can see more detail and it's something I notice (but some people don't). Also the V30 has a useful wide angle camera, very fun to use. The microphone is much better since they have 3 microphones on it and video recording software is more advanced. The DAC is a plus, music sounds much better and clearer, it's noticable. I'm not biased because I've been using Samsung phones for many years including the S8+. It all comes down to preference from here, if you're okay with the awkward shape of the S8+, then go for it because it's a great phone. Bixby is actually pretty good and useful.

I've still got both the Note 8 and the V30. I had the S8+ for 5 months prior to upgrading to the Note. 
I think given what you said about the edge bothering you, you know the answer. Personally I love the edge. On the Note, it's far less pronounced, but I loved it on the S8+.
The call quality is about the same on Band 12 LTE (Voice over LTE for T-Mobile). The V30 is the only one of the two to support T-Mobile's latest band for rural areas, but since you're on AT&T, that won't matter.
I've had more weird Bluetooth issues with the V30. It sometimes randomly disconnects from me car (2017 Golf R), my Beats X headset, and my Bose QC35s. So I do think it has less stable Bluetooth than the Samsung. 
Batter life on the V30 is better, particularly standby time. The screen on the S8+ is somewhat nicer, but the V30 is more than good enough. 
If you like audio and have good headphones, the V30 has no competition in the market. 
For instant photos where you don't have time to think, just quickly pull out the phone and snap a photo, the Samsung wins every time. If you have a bit more time, you can get better shots out of the V30.
The only other complaint I have about the V30 is that it feels extremely light. Too light for me, but I'm putting a heavy case on it to make up for that (Spiegen Tough Armor).

I've had both the international unlocked s8+ and now the v30 on AT&T, and I can tell you I absolutely do not miss the bad fingerprint sensor or having to disable the bixby button and software. otherwise, the phones are very very close. I'd be happy with either. I like the v30 a bit more with the dual camera set-up

I had the S8+ and now using the V30. Samsung has a bigger screen and bigger battery. Nicer screen to me. Back cameras are a toss up but the V30 has a wide angle. FFC is Samsung all the way. Better fingerprint location on V30. The Quad dac is awesome if you listen to music on the V30. I really liked using Samsung Pay

I have the S8+, not thrilled with the 18:9 ratio, the curved edges, built-in battery, etc. Only got it because of the Black Friday's deal at Best Buy. It's so totally not worth the retail price. 400 - maybe? 800, def not.

Just got the V30+ and I noticed it has a grainy screen. It's more obvious when the brightness is below 80% on gray and white backgrounds. Compared to the IPS on the LG V20 it's so bad that I can't ignore it. To make it more clear I do not have the color banding issue.

title: Did you get any scratches on the back glass yet?

thread.text: From what I remembered, the iPhone 4 (which started this glass phone idea) got scratches from the back after months with a case on it. Dirt and debris will get in-between the case and phone, therefore scratching the fine glass underneath. Do you see any scratches on it? What about the metallic paint on the bezel? Tip: use a bright LED flashlight. Just curious, if I do get the V30 I might wrap the back with a protective film.

replies.text: I use no protective cases or films, and I have no marks or scratches. I have also dropped the phone once or twice.
Wow - that's one sturdy phone!
Did you use a flashlight? Might have micro scratches
Yep. Visually, I don't see any traces of micro scratches. I'm also not using a microscope to take a closer look at the surface.

title: Does the V30 send and receive MMS messages (pictures, GIFs etc) while connected to WiFi?

thread.text: I previously had an S8+ and the phone would NOT send MMS messages while connected to a WiFi network. I went through multiple tech calls with ATT and even contacted Samsung and nothing would fix it. I really want away from Apple and want to get the V30 but not if I’ll run into the same issues as I did with the S8+. I need to be able to send MMS messages while connected to WiFi.

replies.text:
Hello there!
I'm really hoping that other V30 owners will also give their responses (because I suspect this might be an issue also related to carrier and not just phone, but as far as I know, I AM able to send MMS while on wi-fi.
Then again, I'm on T-Mobile and my carrier provides VoLTE and wi-fi calling. In which case, MMS over wi-fi might end up being a carrier thing.
I'll check again and update you so we can be doubly sure.

thread.text:
Welcome to the forums! Not sure if this is region-dependent as well as carrier-dependent; but here in Canada, data needs to be turned on to send MMS messages - at least, with my carrier and those of others, like Bell.
It would be nice for this to not be a thing, though; as I'm very cheap with my data and don't like the idea of sending MMS messages which will affect my usage.

replies.text:
Thanks for the welcome! Even when I Google it I can’t seem to find a trend or common searches like I can with the Samsung phones. 
I am on AT&T and had them trying to help me with my S8+ and they kept insisting it’s supposed to work. They eventually took the phone back even though it was outside of their return day policy. I’m just trying to avoid that again...

Hi again!
Sorry for the wait, but yes, I was able to confirm that I AM able to receive MMS through wi-fi on this phone. My coworker MMSed me by sending me photos via SMS / MMS. I was on wi-fi only and the multiple images were all received.
Something to consider: I'm on T-Mobile and my carrier provides wi-fi calling which includes - or should include - MMS over wi-fi.
So, the V30 is capable of MMS over wi-fi. But like @Morty2264 said, this may be a question that has to be settled by your / the mobile carrier.

Wow, the system lost my response from yesterday....
Yes, the LG V30 can do SMS and MMS over wifi when wifi-calling is turned on.
Unfortunately, your carrier plays a roll here. With AT&T, only SMS works on wifi-calling; MMS (photos or long text) requires mobile data.
Does it? I know with T-Mobile, Sprint, and Verizon when you use WiFi calling it can send MMS over WiFi.

I thought I could send MMS over ATT, too, but my last set of tests for this thread all failed while trying lots of settings changes. I remember being able to do so previously, but maybe I am not remembering correctly.
Edit:
Looks like it is Textra that is causing the MMS failure on wifi-calling. If I switch back to the default "messaging" app, MMS does go through on ATT wifi-calling.
In which case, I guess I should add to my post that I was and am using the V30's default messaging app.

Actually, I discovered while on the T-Mo forums for something else that some people with the Samsung phones were complaining of the same thing.
It makes me think that maybe there's some setting in the device that was / is interfering somehow.
Then again, some of them were using Textra which @ManiacJoe just talked about.

During my research while having the S8+ I came across someone saying that there seemed to be an issue with the phone switching between cellular data and WiFi when sending and receiving MMS while connected to a WiFi network. I don’t know how much truth is in that but I tried every setting I could find. I even tried other messaging apps. Well I couldn't handily find a battery life thread so I decided to create one.
I am absolutely loving the battery life on my Silver V30. I am using it on T-Mobile. 
I started paying attention on the amazing battery life on this device only in the last couple of days.
49+ hours off the charger.
4 hours 45 minutes Screen On Time
20% battery life remaining.
Phone Idle used 22%
Screen used 14% 
I am sure I can squeeze out a bit more SOT time if I use it heavily in one day!
I have a friend who is reporting 10 hour SOT - that is very good.
What type of battery life stats are you getting?
Sound off here on the forums.
Try PCMark Work2.0 battery life test.
Wow, what great battery life! Let us know what you get next! I've heard very good things about battery life - I think my friend charges his only every other day.

The V30 is my first phone with non-removable battery, the concept which I'm still trying to digest. Whether I keep it for 2+ years or switch to something else in a year, preserving the battery longentivity is important (to me).
My charging strategy - 
-Never charge the battery above 90%, charge up to 80% when possible
-Don't charge to 100% and leave on charger
-Never discharge to below 20%, preferably 30%
-Avoid fast charging and wireless charging that causes the battery to heat up excessively. Battery heat is bad for Lithium batteries. I've taken my fast charge and QC chargers and use 5V, 2A output chargers instead. 
To accomplish this I carry around a 6,400 mAh Anker battery pack. I also carry other gear so the battery pack isn't a big deal.
Bottom line - using the above guidelines I still only have to charge once a day, but instead of charging up to 100% each night and leaving it on the charger at 100% for 6 hours, use a more active approach.

replies.text:
I really do like your approach. Even though batteries are tougher nowadays, threads like these have me wondering if I'm putting unnecessary strain on mine. I let it sit on the charger; though I often make a point to unplug it from my bedside outlet if I happen to wake up during the night. I also give my phone "top-up" charges at least once a day so I think that is a bad habit that should be broken.
I've heard the V30 has great battery longevity; but I can definitely understand your wanting to keep the battery healthy. Good for you!

thread.text:
I'm consistently topping 4.5+ hr SOT at about 20% left. And usually the phone has been off charger for 30+ hours.
Yesterday I got that battery life despite heavy use of headphone and making that DAC work hard.

A shot in the dark and excuse me if I'm being obvious (I'm kind of new), but do you have -all- the location settings on including location sharing or are there exclusions that might affect functionality?
I've discovered that Google can and does share location information around with other apps including its own processes.
If you want to try troubleshooting some more and if you haven't tried already:

My phone seems to offer multiple layers of data usage and location usage control. Being that I'm kind of new to Android, I'm not sure if it's the OS or LG itself or both, but all these options might affect app behaviors in ways a little unexpected.

title: Phone Lost Cellular connection....now working again sort of

thread.text:
So I was using my LG v30 yesterday
no issues
no drops
lived entire life in a case
then I suddenly lost my 4g lte connection--and all ceullar connection--just a big old X there
wifi fine
tried going to airplane mode and off
power cycled phone
took sim card out and back in
nothing
took to t mobile and got a new sim card
still nothing
about ready to do a warranty replacement when I tried to do a network reset and that has fixed it
I hope its a momentary hickup and not a sign there are issues with the sim reader inside the phone.
Anyone else have this? first time this has happened to me that required a full network reset.
well upon network reset I've lost access to tmobile digits. This phone supports it natively in dialer and messages app with built in multi-line support--which is now missing--I guess its a return.
It sure sounds like it. Something is slowly going wrong. (If the phone has ever gotten wet, of you moved a warm phone with humid air in it into a cold environment, that could be a cause.)

hmm, not that cold/warm in seattle...but acting weird for sure. And 3 hours later after talking to tmobile support, reset, backup, restore, retry, test this, they finally will send out a replacement, which won't ship until monday, which means maybe tuesday...but at least I have a backup phone.
My Lg V30 was working fine and was purchased oct 5th--its only a few months old, always in a case, no major drops. I hope Lg V30s are going to have the same bootloop/motherboard issues of prior lg phones.

well, spent hours on chat with tmobile to convince them the phone had a hardware issue, they eventually agreed to send me a warranty replacement (bought from them direct at full price)
went to gym today and then noticed no signal again. Another network reset brought it back, but it is not a long term solution. and this is AFTER I had to do a factory reset to convince tmobile to get me a replacement. So I am glad I am getting a replacement. This was a bought right when they first came out with manufracture date of 9/2017. Screen, everything was perfect before this, so I hope we don't see a bunch of failing LG v30s

replies.text: You're the first I've heard with this issue, so probably an isolated incident of a bad handset. It happens to all manufacturers.

If Outlook is used for work I strongly suggest the app Nine. Not free but worth every penny. Outlook will improve over time, but for now - not good.

replies.text: This
Nine is so far superior to Outlook, there really is no comparison. Best Exchange email client for any phone that I've used period.
I use outlook for my work email, what am I missing out on?

thread.text: does nine sync with the contacts app on Android so you can use the phonebook

replies.text: It won't sync your entire AD contact list to your Android Contacts. But it will sync the ones you saved as contacts in Desktop Outlook as far as I can tell.

thread.text: what about blue mail?

replies.text:
Blue Mail takes a shortcut by saving data on AWS servers. This could be very bad if security is a concern. Nine doesn't host your emails in the cloud, which programitically is more complicated than Blue Mail's aproach. 
CapDad, Nine can sync contacts with Android. Since I use it only for work I don't select that.
Note this was over a year ago - my knowledge of Blue Mail. Possible they changed their app. Other than that, Blue Mail worked fine with Outlook / MS Exchange. Nine is a reasonably secure app and recommended for MS Exchange environments. 
In summary, both work fine. Nine is $14.99 and Bluemail is free, and doesn't have ads. Chances are your IT department would rather pay the $14.99 for Nine.

thread.text: using nine and it's a nice app. I did like some of the features on blue mail but I think from a security standpoint nine is better. Outlook just couldn't keep up with the interface and speed

title: Strange WIFI Behavior... Only @ Work & Nobody Else Experiences This

thread.text:
Just recently, every time I attempt to connect to the (public) WIFI at work I get connected and then immediately get a WIFI disabled message.
I can connect to ALL other public WIFI's no matter where I go.
Nobody else who uses the public WIFI at work has this issue.
I did a 'Network settings reset', but that didn't make a difference. On some thread, it was recommended doing some playing around with turning on/off Airplane mode. That didn't make a difference.
Rather than go to a more generalized AC thread, I thought I'd throw it out there for the folks on this forum. TIA for any ideas of things to try. If it is something really simple, I'll feel bad but I'd like to know what I can do.

I've seen this happen before, but it wasn't specific to this phone or even Android.
If YOU haven't changed any settings and it used to work fine, then it's likely an issue with your work's connection.
Do any of your coworkers have a similar issue?
Can you still connect to the wi-fi using other devices?
That said, and it's a shot in the dark, but I'm wondering if it's possible your device got blocked from the network for some reason.

replies.text:
Anyone I've asked has no issues with work's public WIFI.
I'll try my hubby's phone the next time we're there together.
I use to be (way in my career past) a network person, so I understand the blocking idea. I can't imagine why and don't have a lot of confidence in asking their IT department to look into it. Again, this is another path to investigate.
Thanks for the thoughts/suggestions.

thread.text:
I forgot to note that I brought my eReader into work the other day and it connected just fine to the public WIFI.
*****
I had a chance to talk to a Verizon tech yesterday and they told me to see if I could connect to the public WIFI at work in Safe-Mode. The tech said that he has had multiple customers with Motorola's (him included) who cannot connect to certain public WIFI's as he said certain routers don't 'play nice' with certain phone manufacturers. He did say that I would be the first LG one where he is having a customer try this route. 
He also said he would like to avoid a total reset, but because I have just about everything backed up that that wouldn't be too (yeah, right) time consuming to get my phone back to where I like it to be. 
He commented that it was too bad that LG doesn't do a good job at marketing as he has played with the V30 and talked to customers who love their device.
I'll keep y'all posted.

replies.text: It didn't work and I'm debating if I think it is worth the hassle to do a device reset just for connecting to WIFI at work. I don't use it for much unless I cannot get to a computer to look up stuff for my customers.

title: Looking for Tips to Manual Mode - LG V30 Graphy/RAW/Lightroom - beginner

thread.text:
OK, so I've got a lot to learn about manual mode Graphy and RAW images... and then adobe lightroom too. Before I go to far, it will soon be obvious that I'm a complete novice in photography. 
Keep in mind,I am already pleased with the pictures I'm getting without changing up the camera too much - yes, I like auto mode too. Don't give me cr@p about that . I'm looking at this as a potential enhancement to what I think are already great pictures. 
I have Graphy installed, though as much as I love the idea of Graphy I always get a message telling me I'm over or under exposed. I thought the idea was to select a similar image and use the settings the original photographer used. It's weird because I choose an outside daytime Graphy while I'm outside taking a daytime picture and the entire screen will darken, tell me I'm underexposed and need to adjust ISO. I assumed Graphy was doing that work for me. 
I downloaded the free version of adobe lightroom to my phone. I took a 'RAW' picture of a Christmas tree. I was surprised to see the JPEG that came out was clearer than the RAW... and that the 'RAW' also didn't include the zoom I had on the tree.
I did open the RAW in free Android lightroom, cropped and edited, but really have no idea what the heck I'm doing. It looked better than the original RAW, but ..ehh
So, advice, tips, tricks... all the above would be great. This is with the V30 Stock Manual mode and not using Google Camera. 
I'll get to that another time, but first things first... 
Anyone have the time to share tips/tricks? 
Rick

The trick is knowing what you want the image to look like.
Since the lens aperture is fixed, you do not get to choose the depth of field like you would with a DSLR.
Shutter speed: what is the blur effect desired for your subject and your hands?
You will want a shutter speed fast enough to stop the shake of your hands (as most people wrongly hold the camera).
If the subject is moving, do you want to freeze the action or blur it to show the motion?
Sports usually need a speed of 1/500 or higher to freeze the action.
ISO: controls how sensitive to the light the sensor is.
In low light, you will need a higher ISO to get higher shutter speeds.
Unfortunately, higher ISOs lead to more digital noise being seen.
Digital noise can be fixed in software during post production; motion blur cannot be fixed.
How I shoot in manual mode:
I usually start in manual mode by tapping the "auto" button (bottom, far right).
I then tap the screen to set the focus point on the subject, which also sets the exposure target.
I then check the shutter speed. I usually have a minimum speed in mind to handle my hands and any subject motion.
I then adjust the ISO to get the desired brightness I want, which may or may not be what the camera recommends.
Knowing that I am going to edit the photo, I usually just go with the auto white balance in the camera then fix it in the edits later if needed. This is an easy fix for DNG files, very hard for JPG files.
Software editing:
All my pictures (phone and DSLR) get processed. On what device and using what software depends on the use of the photo.
DSLR pics and important phone pics gets processed in Lightroom Classic on my PC.
Other phone pics get processed on the phone using either "snapseed" or "photoshop express".
If you are going to do a large crop, do it first to get rid of the stuff you don't want to see.
Fix the white balance first. This makes all other edits much easier.
Most people like warmer (yellowish) to cooler (bluish), but don't go crazy.
If you are going to do a curves adjustment (good for large exposure problems) do it next.
Adjust the highlights and shadows, whites and blacks before adjusting the "brightness".
Adjust the "brightness" which tends to affect the midrange most.
Adjust the vibrance before adjusting the saturation.
Adjust the "clarity", but gently.
Adjust the contrast last.
Noise reduction: you need much less then you think. No one sees your image at 100% zoom. The size reduction needed to print or view on the screen naturally eats a lot of noise to start with.
Sharpening: go gently, creating halos is bad. 
If your software allows for masking, set it really high, like 80/100. You are looking to sharpen the transitions, not the noise in the flat colors.

I agree with @ManiacJoe.
Shooting in manual mode requires fiddling with the settings that you want. In my experience, I've discovered that there is always a bit of variance in how each camera interprets settings. Fine tuning helps a lot.

@ManiacJoe
Joe - awesome! Thanks for taking the time to put together this well articulated and easy to understand response. 
Seriously... going to take your advice and get cracking on some pictures this weekend. 
With any luck I'll have something to share for advice and feedback. 
For 'sports' in your example... I'd prefer to get the subject in focus and the rest of the field of vision to be 'background'. If blurred is the only way so be it. So, for example if I'm at a hockey game I want a picture of the guy with the puck taking a slapshot. The rest of the ice/arena isn't as important. 
So, is that where you're suggesting "a speed of 1/500 or higher to freeze the action."?
Last question - am I correct that a 'RAW' image will not allow for zoom and will require cropping etc. after the fact? 
I'll post a couple of things early next week. Granted, what I like may not be what everyone else does... but I'd like some constructive feedback. I'm new in photo editing software too. I have a Mac, so not sure what free software I could use for that. I do own pixelmator. I also downloaded lightroom to my phone. 
I'll post to Flickr as it saves the settings I used for the actual photo. 
By the way, if I edit the photo, will Flikr or anyone else for that matter still be able to tell what iso/shutter speed I used or does all that disappear after editing?
Thanks so much again for answering all these questions and for being patient with me. 
Rick

replies.text:
Unfortunately, with hockey the motion is mainly the stick and puck. In some other sports you can follow the player (or horse, in racing) and get a clear shot of the subject with the background blurry. You can try bracing against something solid and following the player with the puck, but the stick and puck will still be blurred unless the shutter speed is high enough.There are two types of picture, raster and vector. Raster is little blocks, and if you zoom in post production, the blocks just get larger, so the quality goes down. And RAW is a raster format. (A vector format is just a description - from here, in this color to there. If you zoom, the length in the description changes but the quality doesn't. But cameras use raster images.) You can crop the picture, then change the size, as long as changing the size doesn't turn it into blobs of colors. (A 3:1 zoom isn't too bad, a 10:1 zoom will make it unrecognizable.)
The secret is to pay with it. It;s not as if you're wasting film - just delete the bad ones.
As far as you problems with Graphy, it shows you the settings that a good picture with that lighting was taken with - you set your camera to the same settings.

Adding my 2 cents to the good response by @RukbatThis is where the shallow depth of field comes in from a lens with a wide opening. On your camera, you have a lens with a fixed aperture at whatever it is. With a DSLR you would want a pro-level zoom lens with an aperture of f/2.8 or some prime lenses with apertures at f/1.8 or f/1.4.In the case of ice hockey, you have the motion of the skating player and the motion of the swinging stick and puck. 1/500 may get the player frozen, but maybe not his swinging arm and the stick and puck. You will need to decide how much motion blur is acceptable to you.
Another example: I shoot lots of high school volleyball in poorly lighted gyms { f/2.8, ISO 6400, 1/640 }. At 1/640, I get frozen bodies, frozen legs, frozen heads. However the ball and the hitting hand are often slightly blurred. While I don't mind the slight blur as it shows action, some of the guys I shoot with prefer no blur at all so they are shooting at a minimum of 1/1000 shutter speed at whatever high ISO that requires.Raw/DNG from your phone probably does not allow for in-camera cropping. In-camera digital zoom is just in-camera cropping. (Phones do not do optical zooming.)All that data is contained in the EXIF data of the image.
Some editors remove it, some keep it.
Some hosting sites keep the EXIF data in the image, some sites will separate the data from the image but still display the data, some sites discard the EXIF data.
I think that Flickr separates the data from the image.
Facebook purposely discards the EXIF data.

title: How to best bring up navigation without hitting keyboard

title: LGV30+ A Camera as good as a DSLR... and a Signature!

thread.text:
As you’ve already heard from me, I LOVE the camera on the LG V30+ more than on any other device. It’s weird to me that some people would refute the fact that this camera is so good. The pictures I’m taking are (to me) better than my high quality Nikon camera.
Anyway, with social media being what it is and your pictures & media available to all to poach without giving proper credit to the photographer (you) it brings me great pleasure to introduce you to the ‘Signature’ feature built into the LG V30+ Camera software.
So, this blog is really a mishmash ofa couple of things... 
First, I post a quite a few pictures on social media. Most days there’s a picture from my morning jog down the East side of Manhattan. Lately it’s been more ‘pre-dawn’ with the move to daylight savings. 
I recently had a comment from a photographer friend on Facebook asking me what camera I’ve been using to post my photos as she’s looking to replace her DSLR. Yeah, she likes the pictures I’ve taken with the LGV30+ enough to think about replacing her DSLR camera… THAT says a lot about the quality of these pictures. OK - perhaps it's not 'as good' as a DSLR as my title states, but to many people, this is definitely close enough. When I saw her post I literally smiled from ear to ear. 
I’m not a heavy user of ‘filters’ as most times when I find inspiration in something worth shooting I want to grab the true natural colors. Not that I'm against using them from time to time. Still one of the things I love about the LG V30+ Camera is the colors are true/real life. It’s not augmented or affected by the software or lens like some other flagship devices. If I want to add the filters myself, they’re easily accessible. The photo of the Williamsburg Bridge, NY is on 'Auto Mode' with no filters... You can view the settings on Flikr. 
The photo my friend commented on is below… and a full HD version is available here –Williamsburg Bridge Full HD Picture on Flikr 
Williamsburg Bridge - FB
The other thing I wanted to note is the ‘signature’ on the bottom right of the picture. Basically you can set a ‘watermark’ (signature) on your pictures to ensure you’re identified as the rightful owner of your work. Sure… people can still borrow shamelessly from your photos and photoshop them, etc… but, this makes it a little bit harder while making your amazing pictures even more personal.
To add a signature to your pictures open the Camera App > Click the Settings Cog in the upper left corner > Scroll to ‘Signature’ and click the 3 dots > Type in your signature and choose your font and click ‘ADD’.
Tip – the keyboard pops up and covers up some of the additional font options. Shrink the keyboard down to see the additional fonts.
Tip 2 – you can view a sample of your Signature at the top of the screen over a picture of tulips.
After you click ‘Add’ you’ll be brought back to the settings screen. Just make sure ‘Signature’ is set to on and you’re all set. From here on out you’ll have your signature on all of your photos. 
Signature Settings
Adding a Signature
Additional Fonts
That's' all I've got for now. Got some great pictures? Feel free to share them here. 
Questions about the LG V30+? ask away... 
Until next time - Have a GREAT Holiday Season!

thread.text: Aside from seeing the system drain, you can't anymore. I believe with 7.0, Android shut off the capability for apps to see which other apps are running or using battery. No idea why, but they did.

On my ATT branded V30 the battery usage is at
settings > general > battery & power saving > battery usage 
Then scroll down to "details"

My T-Mobile branded V30+ lets me see, too.
Conveniently, the Battery Usage setting is also accessible in the Smart Cleaning icon (which handily also includes the Optimize Phone feature along with the Battery Saver and Test Hardware feature) that's tucked away in my LG's out-of-the-box Maintenance folder.
For me, on Maximum Battery Saver, and with my routine usage, I've lasted 34+ hours with about an hour and a half to spare. This includes listening to three+ consecutive hours of Hi-Fi music, intermittent Chrome browsing, all-day Skype Lite texting, all-day fiddling, downloading some of my app library, and a bit of this and that.Don't know about anyone else, but Chrome along with Google Play Store can be battery vampires for me. I've left both on in the background and when I later checked my battery usage after, Chrome was the undisputed leader in both battery draining and memory hogging with Google Play Store right behind.
Even Skype which is notorious in any format for being a vampire wasn't that bad and I was texting like mad on it during the same time and when I wasn't, it was also in the background.
My solution was to disable background activities as much as I can along with data usage (I personally don't have anything related to either of the two that needs constant background refreshing or data usage) and it helped.
If you can get into Battery Usage, you can actually click on all of the listed apps and/or features and/or functionalities and do a compare and contrast.
A tip that I was told when I was struggling to figure out why my Android tablet's screen kept turning on by itself was to check for any apps that are 'Keep Awake' when they don't necessarily need to be.
I checked the apps/features/functions in my V30 that were the top offenders and wouldn't you know? The Google Play Store has a Keep Awake function and it was indeed awake and it had indeed been awake when it didn't need to be.
Don't know if any of this rings any bells for you, but that's my experience so far.

How do I go about checking the keep awake function? I went to settings/apps but could not find the functions part.
I'm new to android so I sure I'm just missing something.

replies.text:
Even though I knew of the existence of function, I only discovered 'proof' of it in my V30 by accident myself so you're not alone!Settings -> General -> Under the Phone Management heading -> Battery & power saving -> Click on Battery usage.
This will pull up a list of your general stats on battery usage per app or certain phone functions or features (like Android's various system operations).
To see exact statistics for each app/function/feature, simply click on any of the listings.
Using Android System as an example, if you click it, you'll see a whole list of stats - CPU total, CPU background, etc. - and Keep Awake is amongst them and it lists for how long... which makes sense because it's our phone's OS.
If you look at something like Music, you'll probably also see a Keep Awake stat for it, too, which makes sense because it plays in the background and the album art can be shown on the lock screen.
On the other hand, if you look at an example like Chrome, depending on how aggressive your browser settings are, you may or may not see any Keep Awake statistics. Chrome is a resource hog for me and I seldom if ever need it to run in the background and so I'm very aggressive in making sure it uses as little resources (including data) as possible. 
That said, I hope that helps and as some suggestion: if you've updated any apps lately, give them a looksee to see if any of your settings might have changed - especially if you use any particular clock, alarm, or nighttime-related settings.
Automatic app updates might also be contributing; for me, I've had it set so that it will update apps through Wi-Fi only... but if I let them auto-update, too, I might have apps updating throughout the night while I sleep because at home, I'm on Wi-Fi.
I agree with tardus; if it still isn't making sense, post a screenshot of the Battery Usage screen and maybe we can help troubleshoot.

--- be warned, this is a rant.
I ordered my phone at a local dealer three weeks ago.
Now I got a mail, that due to delivery Problems by LG, the phone will probably arrive mid January!!
Honestly?
I mean: yes, LG, you finally brought a great phone out and showed it to us in September. You then took another month to release it in the US. It took you till end of November to release it in Germany.
We here in Austria, bordering Germany, might not be the biggest market, but our 9 mil people are statistically using 3 phones per person. Austria is also a reference market for mobile Technology. UMTS and LTE were first tested here and our network coverage is one of the best world wide, as well as the wonderfully low rates for speech and data (I pay 13,- € for 3000 min speech, 3000 SMS and unlimited data - 17GB full speed LTE).
So yes, maybe we're not the biggest market. Maybe were not known so well and not so much in your Focus, LG. But believe me, due to your ridiculous marketing, you aren't in our focus that much either - and from what I hear, you're not that much in the focus with your mobile phones anywhere else, too.
This, and the fact that it's taking you MONTHS to get your product out in Europe means only one thing: people buy Samsungs S8+ or Note 8, which are significally getting cheaper over time, people buy the Huawei Mate 10 Pro which is a great phone and also cheaper than yours, heck, people might even buy iPhones, which are decent enough and have one big advantage: availability.
What the f*** is the matter with you, LG? Dou you really need to be told, that to earn money you need to sell your sh*t to people? And for people to buy your sh*t you need to offer it to them?
Dangling great products infront of your customers nose without giving them the ability to buy them is complete and utter nonsense. Your competitors have good products and have them available and are getting cheaper every month. You are loosing customers every day!
I really have to rethink now, of I wait that long or if I go for the Mate 10 Pro or (if it get's cheaper) the Pixel 2XL.
Shame on you, LG.
/rant
Sorry for the burst. But some psycho-hygiene was direly needed and I am sure, I am not the only one out there, who is fed up...

title: LGV30+ Holiday's in NYC Pics and Audio Recordings

thread.text:
Yes, it's that time of year. Holidays are in full effect... especially here in NYC. Thanksgiving has passed and the spirit is flowing. OK, not to make anyone throw up from holiday cheer or anything like that... just sometimes it's good to stop and appreciate the season. 
So, here's what I'm going to do... Post some of my New York City Holiday Photos and audio clips to show you how awesome they came out with my LG V30+. 
PLEASE feel free to respond with your photo's too! 
I went to the Vienna Boys Choir this past weekend. It's been a holiday tradition for the last 5 or so years. It's so innocent... kids from all around the world together to sing choir music as well as Christmas songs in the greatest music venue in the world - Carnegie Hall.
Though you're not really supposed to take pictures during the performance, I did sneak in one shot before and two just at the start of the show.
I also got a few 'concert' recorded tracks with the LG V30+ sitting on my lap.
Was far up in a box at the back of the theater, so will share my pictures from that vantage and the audio too... just keep in mind the positioning and the fact that I had to be discrete.
I am SO impressed with the audio recording capabilities of this phone. Seriously, Stereo recording (in concert mode only) with super defined clarity. Sorry it's so quiet though - I was a bit far back as you can see from the pictures and well.. it's not like a Rock Concert that would have been much louder (which I promise to record next).
Even if it's not your type of music, you have to at least appreciate the innocence of it all. I know, it may not be your thing, but please don't bash...
Feel free to zoom in (enlarge) on these photos too as you'll see the clarity and definition.
ALL pictures are on Auto-Mode except the one in VR of the tree.
One thing I noticed is if you do choose to zoom/enlarge these pictures, the ones that aren't 'zoomed' via the V30+ have a lot more sharpness and clarity than those which we're zoomed via the camera. 
3 Pictures from the Vienna Boys Choir:
3 Audio Tracks from the Vienna Boys Choir - unedited. Volume is a bit low:https://drive.google.com/open?id=1Mb...zobhgbn89-Dbrxhttps://drive.google.com/open?id=1Q1...pJWOX1XuQJlS2Yhttps://drive.google.com/open?id=1au...Oxzia7Suxg3E8C
On my walk from Carnegie Hall to Rockefeller Center I happened to walk past St. Patrick's Cathedral. The crowds around the area were insane! You could barely walk because of the number of people taking pictures of Sack's 5th Avenue Windows and of course the tree being right there. So, as not to be like all the rest and block the sidewalk while taking pictures, I snapped 2 super fast shots of the Cathedral and pushed my way along with the rest of the crowd.
The colors and background are amazing. If you zoom in on these you'll see it's almost like 3D.
This camera is just amazing...
And now the Tree. I took a couple from further back near the sidewalk entrance off 5th, and then squeezed my way right up front.
I shared these pictures (on the phone) with a couple of friends last night and they were more impressed with the quality of the pictures than of the actual tree. lol
I probably should mention, I don't know any of the people in these pictures. They just happened to be in the way  haha.
First the VR. This is for those who have always wished they could visit NYC and participate in Rockefeller Center this time of year. 
For the full 180° you may have to go to the link here... 
Should be 180 VR, but not sure how this will show here. Check the link  otherwise. 
And then the other Tree Pictures.. 
This one from the street - notice I focused on the Tree, therefore the people who I had no interest in taking a photo of are blurred.. plus may have been moving. 
I focused on the tree - no idea who these people are heh
The next is from the same location, but zoomed over the same folks heads... Killer zoom! 
Zoomed in from 5th ave (practically) to the tree. Great Detail for zoom.
...and the remaining from right up front.. All in Auto Mode 
Wide Angle - 
- share some Holiday pictures from your V30+ or any other phone.. and have a very very Happy Holiday Season!

Rick

So, I just switched to Android from Windows Phone after being a very happy Windows user for a decade. Something I'm used to just working is Cortana's Driving Mode. It would automatically start when my phone paired to the Bluetooth in my car & it would announce all calls & text messages and allow me to respond to texts with voice dictation. These announcements would automatically pause whatever audio I had coming from my phone, or present itself as a "phone call" and Ford Sync would interrupt radio to allow the announcement to be made. All other notifications would be silenced. I could say Hey Cortana whenever & ask it to do whatever I wanted it to. It worked & it worked well.
Since switching to Android a month ago, I have been frustrated beyond words. I've used Android Auto, Car Dashdroid, & Drivemode apps. It's all trash. While driving, my phone constantly locks up & doesn't notify me when I get texts. It just goes crazy. I don't need or want a driving interface. I don't want anything to draw over the screen, & I don't want there to be tons of complicated options. Cortana for Android doesn't have near the functionality that it's Windows 10 Mobile counterpart has, so that's not an option. I just want something similar to what I'm used to. Something that works without being intrusive or slowing my phone down. Can someone help me please?
Signed,
A frustrated Android user that misses his Windows Phone

Welcome to Android Central! Which phone do you have? It's odd that Android Auto is problematic -- it's been very smooth and helpful for me. When I get a text message (or a Hangouts message), I see a very prominent notification appear, with a big fat Play button to tap. Music then pauses while the system reads the message, and then asks me if I want to reply. It's possible that some other app you're using is interfering with Android Auto's function (especially since it sounds like something might be causing a Screen Overlay).
If you don't want to use any kind of driving mode or app, you can always say "Ok Google, show me my last messages." You'll be prompted to have them read to you if you want, and then you'll have the option to respond.
What you describe is a fairly common complaint from users who have used Windows Phone, so you're not alone. Hopefully, the many strengths of Android will help compensate!

So far, in my limited experience with Android, this may be a common complaint from previous Windows Phone/Windows Mobile users. But with good reason. The Android experience doesn't come close.
My phone stays in my pocket always while driving. Absolutely no visual or physical interaction. The Cortana on Windows perpetuated that. It would announce text messages, offer to read/ignore/reply etc. Cortana on Android doesn't come close, and so far as I know nor does any alternative (please correct me if I'm wrong).

LG is making the hardware for Google, so they take a very different approach. I've got mine running as close as I want it to stock Pixel, but I use a lot of Nova features well beyond that.
Nova allows you to get the swipe to the right to get to Google Home, it offers Oreo's notification system, and you can use the Pixel IP icon pack to get the look and feel of the Pixel.
Settings still won't be the same of course. I use a LG dark theme so that settings and the notification slide down are both dark.
Beyond that, I use a lot of icon folders, a Nova and Action feature that lets you show a top app icon only for a folder that may have a bunch of other icons in it. A swipe up on the app icon shows the rest of the apps in the folder. Here's one of my home pages and the same one showing that the Netflix app is actually a folder with all my TV/Entertainment apps. I'm using the Active UX icon pack at the moment, which has the icons in Samsung S7/Note 8 style. I switch between that and Pixel IP.

title: Earbuds that will take full advantage of DAC

thread.text: I have a great pair of Sennheiser HD 598 headphone (50 ohms) that sound terrific with the V30 DAC, but of course they’re not very portable. I also have a pair of SoundMagic E10 Noise Isolating earbuds (in-Ear 47 ohms) that sound very good, but I’m wondering if there are other earbuds (high impedance) that would use the DAC to its full extent. Does anyone have any suggestions? From what I understand whatever you’re using should be over 50 ohms.

replies.text:
Slhndmagic e80c ...64ohms
Thank me later ;-)

thread.text:
Why would you need high impedance? I don't think that you understand the way that the ES9218P DAC performs. You are talking possibly about engaging the high voltage output circuitry that is needed to power high impedance earphones due to the difficulty in driving them. The high output is NOT engaged in lower impedance earphones because doing so would cause the audible noise floor to increase (hiss in the background.) The resolution/clarity/dynamic range does not change when using high or low impedance earphones, just the perceived volume.
The best way to take advantage of the ES9218P DAC in the V30 is:
1. Use music that was RECORDED in high-resolution
2. Only use the stock LG music player
3. Use a headphone or earphone with a frequency range that extends above 30khz

replies.text:
Poweramp app should takes full advantage of the DAC - but alpha3 build-704 is needed according to what I've read.
. And number three - most adults can't hear a above 20Khz. But quality eaphones extend beyond 30Khz typically. I think this is an odd way to assess earphone quality. Intead of looking at Khz, read reviews at audiphile sites, such as Head-Fi.org.
Good luck!

Nope! The ONLY app that will send PCM>192khz, DSD and MQA to the ES9218P DAC in the V30, is the stock player. I have tested 14 players and none of the others will work correctly with all audio files, including Poweramp.
Quality is equally important to frequency range, but it is easier to give a solid spec that WILL take full advantage of the ES9218P DAC in this unit which is the original posters question.
There are so many things wrong with these statements being presented as facts that it's beyond belief.

thread.text: Thanks for clearing that up. I guess I thought the high output mode was "better".

replies.text: Nope, just louder for headphones that are hard to drive to decent volume levels.

thread.text: Yeah same sentiment, don't need high impedance for great sound.
So, Mike Dee, is there any advantage to using high impedance devices or not?

replies.text: Not on the V30..its a smartphone not a dedicated Power/Amp/DAC . Lets be real here. You want the full potential for over the ear headphones then get ready to pony up some dollars for a good DAC like the iDSD Black Label or the MoJo Chord for example. IEM will suit better on the v30 imo.

Not based on high impedance alone. LG using using impedance to configure amp output is a grave mistake. The real answer depends on the quality and efficiency of what you're putting in or on your ears.

thread.text:
Dear Folks,
I was thrown off by the following:
Read an article at phonearena - 'How to Turn on and make sense of the LG V30s Quad DAC":
"the "Quad" part means there are actually four DACs stuffed inside a single chip. This lets you use a pair of high-impedance headphones (>50 Ohms), as the three extra DACs kick in only when connected to such a pair. This is designed with audiophiles in mind, as high-impedance headsets are usually much more expensive than regular ones."
Hence I had asked on other forums:
Does it mean that LG's Quad DAC is only useful if one uses 50+ ohm ear(head)phones?
- Will they consume a lot of power?
- Any recommendations in sub $200 category? I have the following in mind - SoundMagic E80
Looking forward to the thoughts of wiser folks.

replies.text: Music sounds beautiful when using my HD25's w/ & V30 together 👍

I wouldn't put full credence in that article. I've heard similar theories for the V20 but never actually comfirmed that it turns on chips on or off. The bottom line is that impedance is a poor standard for which to decide how much output is required. If you dont already have high impendance headphones it will still sound superb with good low impedance headphones. If you decide to invest in high impedance headphones stay away from anything over 250ohms as a rule because some of those are battery killers. There are a few over the ear headphones that around 80 ohms but a very efficient that will work well.

Many Thanks Mike.

It looks good. But doesn't look better than Samsung BC Samsung is the king of AMOLED displays for phones. Only they have the SUPER AMOLED technology, while everyone else has OLED. Personally, I think IPS LCD screens looks brighter and has better whites IMO.

Samsung's Super AMOLED and LG's P-OLED are mostly the same technology. They are both active matrix OLED displays that use plastic substrates and integrated digitizers. There may be differences in the materials they use for the pixel sites and a different pixel layout, but the difference in name is mostly a marketing exercise.
Most phones that have an AMOLED display got them from Samsung. They just can't/don't call them Super AMOLED as Samsung has the term trademarked for their own phones.

I'll stare at the screen a little later on, but I'm 99% sure that my particular device is fine. There is no such lines on my Galaxy S7 flat that is one year old.
2. There is a blue tint when tilting the device that is not an issue with me. When I tilt my Galaxy S7 I don't see any tinting.
That said, the display is perfectly fine, but if compared side by side with the Galaxy S7 you can see that the Samsung display is a little better, especially if viewing at an angle. To be honest, it is not something I would have noticed had I not put the two side by side.
The carrier rep said that they have not had any complaints from customers since I last spoke to her on Friday and sales are going well. The first batch had some returns due to screens, but none lately.
I say if you are worried about the display, then those worries might be behind you. Just make sure you are aware of your carrier's return policies and have a look before settling on the device.
Off topic: Only thing that has me worried so far is that the fingerprint scanner does not like my right index finger (it has a scar). The scanner kept complaining that it was dirty when I was using that finger near where the scarred part is. No other fingerprint scanner has ever had an issue with the scar.
Mine has one faint vertical band just right of center. It's only noticable on a white screen at low brightness settings. But, may see if Verizon will swap it out.

I received mine yesterday was a little worried after everything I've read. I really shouldn't have worried the screen is fine. In normal use including apps and browsing with brightness between 30 - 40% the screen looks fine. I've owned multiple smartphones LCD and OLED and this seems like a lot of fuss about nothing...

Honestly, my biggest complaint about the V30 is how light it it. This is a very subjective thing. To me it just feels very cheap compared to my Note 8 because of how light it is compared to the hefty Note 8. But this is actually completely a non-issue. Most people probably prefer lighter phones, and the build quality of the V30 is outstanding. 
Anyway, I found a case that adds a lot of weight to the V30 and also looks very nice, and am now a lot happier with it. For me, because of its DAC, video camera, etc, there's no question now that I will keep the V30. My only question is whether or not to also sell my Note 8. I can afford to have both of I want to. I prefer some aspects of the Note. But forced to pick only one, it would be the V30.

I bought mine a week ago and I LOVE it!
The screen is the opposite of BAD. I have used a ton of phones over the years, and this screen is one of the best. I've played with the Samsung S8 and Note 8 and while yes, they are beautiful screens, they are not the end all, be all of phones. They have their own problems and issues.
I've also used an iPhone 8 a little, which also has a great screen, but I am not wanting to jump from Android to iOS.
The V30 has a GREAT screen. (at least my particular unit does, and since they are mass produced, that stands to reason I am not the only one with a fantastic screen on his device)

title: Can the LG V30 be used with Strait Talk?

thread.text: It's not listed on their website but I was wondering would it work with an unlocked V30?
An Unlocked V30 should work fine on Straight Talk using AT&T or T-mobile.

replies.text: So (I just want to make sure I understand you completely/correctly) you're saying the unlocked phone needs to have been unlocked from formerly those carriers? So a an unlocked Verizon phone won't work on Straight Talk for example?

You need to purchase a ST SIM card based on the phone original carrier. I.E. if the V30 is from Verizon then you need a ST SIM that works on Verizon towers. Search eBay there are a ton in that marketplace.

thread.text:
If it's locked to AT&T, Sprint, TMobile or Verizon, it should work, but you'd have to check (at Straight Talk Compatibility Test) whether the particular handset will be accepted by the carrier. If it's bought outright it probably will be, but if it's bought from a carrier and not fully paid yet, it won't be.
Since Straight Talk uses AT&T, Sprint, TMobile and Verizon as carriers (ST is only a virtual network, not a carrier), any locked phone (that's AT&T or TMobile - Sprint and Verizon phones are "virtually locked" - if the phone isn't in their database, it won't connect to their network) will work on the appropriate carrier. An unlocked GSM phone will work on either AT&T or TMobile (assuing that it has the right 4G bands - some phones do have radios for both, some don't.),

Hey folks;
Is anyone noticing poor LTE reception on their V30? What I noticed about mine before I sent it back:
1. I was getting '1-2 bars' where other folks would get full strength on the same carrier, in an area that I have had great reception in the past. Using apps such as LTE discovery showed that reception was cutting in and out a lot.
2. HSPA reception was much better when set manually.
3. The phone would not go back to HSPA on its own when LTE reception was poor, leading me to lose data.
4. Other folks in my area on the V30 are seeing the same.
I did the obvious such as get a new SIM, etc. I also recognize that different phones will report signal 'bars' differently, so an app such as LTE discovery that shows signal strength is better. I don't have readings for that right now, but I was told they were on the edge of normal. I also ruled out any settings I might have messed with on the phone, etc.
Can anyone who has seen a difference in LTE reception let me know if they have seen the same? It might be a while before I get the V30 back in my hands, unfortunately.
Sounds like you are on GSM, I know that Sprint users are reporting issues, too, and that is holding me back from buying one.
